## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 49 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 49 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 49 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. The fact that we cannot predict what biobanks will be used for in the future bothers me.
2. The biobank owner should be able to sell any information they have about my genes, if they want to.
3. Profits from biobanking should be shared in some way with the community who provided the samples.
4. I don't mind if my samples are connected to my medical records without my prior permission, so long as researchers don't get access to any data that identifies me.
5. It is acceptable for samples and information that doesn't identify me to be sent to researchers overseas.
6. It's OK if data that identifies me is stored in a separate database and replaced in the biobank by a unique non-identifying code.
7. I should be asked for my permission every time researchers want to use my samples for research
8. We should all provide samples to biobanks because it will benefit everyone.
9. People should be paid for providing their samples to a biobank.
10. My sample should never be permanently anonymized since I should be contacted about important research results
11. Religious groups need to be asked for their views about biobanks and genetic research.
12. Commercial companies should keep all the profits they make from biobanking because they take the financial risks and put up the money to develop new drugs and treatments.
13. Information about people's genes and the traits they inherit from their parents is more private than their medical records.
14. Genetic studies of race on ethnic or cultural groups will lead to the discrimination of those groups.
15. Genetic research will improve our lives.
16. I do not mind if researchers have access to my samples, when there is no way I can be identified.
17. High-priced genetic research is diverting funds that could be used to promote public health in other ways.
18. It is always acceptable to do research on samples that identify me, without my prior permission.
19. Biobanks need to be monitored and reviewed by external, independent people to prevent the misuse of data and samples.
20. People who provide samples for research should get special access to the treatments that result from this research.
21. Biobanks will only lead to high profits and expensive treatments that most people can't afford.
22. Permission from the indigenous community must be sought if samples are collected from indigenous peoples.
23. There is no risk to the people who provide samples and information to biobanks.
24. Collecting samples from people in an ethnic or cultural group is acceptable only if the whole group has agreed to participate.
25. Improved health is more likely to come from educating people about their diet and lifestyle than from biobanks.
26. There must be special consideration of the views of Aboriginal people towards healthcare and genetic research.
27. Researchers and institutions (e.g. hospitals and universities) should be allowed to use samples for research but they should not own them.
28. People should always be able to withdraw their sample from research at any time.
29. Biobanks are valuable even if they only advance science (e.g. provide new information about diseases) and do not lead to treatments or cures.
30. There is no point asking the public for their views on the ethical issues in science and technology.
31. The public will be more protected if biobanks are government-funded not privately funded.
32. Deciding how to regulate biobanks should be left to the government.
33. Commercial companies should get access to biobanks, otherwise new drugs and treatments will not be developed.
34. I trust researchers to make sure only approved people get access to my samples
35. I do not mind if my sample is connected to my name and medical information.
36. Biobanks are valuable because they promise huge benefits for our economy.
37. Policy makers need to consider whether WA should not have biobanks.
38. I trust independent research ethics committees, which are not connected to the biobank in anyway, to decide whether research is ethical and approve who gets access to my samples.
39. People should be told if commercial companies could get access to their samples and information.
40. People who provide samples should be active in the set up and ongoing management of biobanks.
41. The priorities for health should be to reduce inequalities and the burden of disease.
42. The confidentiality of personal medical information is critical in any circumstance where research is being conducted.
43. I trust biobanks with managers who are independent of researchers to make sure only approved people get access to my samples
44. The community that provides samples for research should receive improved medical services in return.
45. Race is a useful topic for genetic studies
46. I should have property rights to my tissues before and after they leave my body
47. People with a [chronic disease or] genetic condition in their family have a responsibility to be involved in genetic research.
48. Public funds should pay for biobanks, instead of private companies.
49. Genetic studies will lead to the discrimination of people living with genetic conditions or disabilities.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 7 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 7 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Minimal Government Input: Minimal input of public resources to development biobanking Use resources  — use instead for other approaches to improving health. Fairly relaxed oversight of use of biobanks and  privacy provisions (low level of regulation).
2. Publicly Funded with minimal regulation: A biobanking system owned and run by the government, who is also responsible for oversight and privacy provisions, as well as controlling access.
3. Cautious Implementation: Minimal input of public resources to development biobanking Use resources  — use instead for other approaches to improving health. Very strict oversight of use of biobanks and strong privacy provisions.
4. Privately Funded with strong regulation: A BB system where funding is provided mostly by private companies, withstrong government oversight and privacy provisions.
5. Publicly Funded with strong regulation: A biobanking system owned and run by the government, who is also responsible for oversight and privacy provisions, as well as controlling access.
6. High Privacy: Implementation of a (publicy or privately owned) biobanking system where privacy of individuals is paramount. Stored data and biological samples for research requires the authorization of individual donors.
7. Privately Funded with minimal regulation: Minimal regulation of privately run biobanking system with maximum participation of the public. Low privacy provisions.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: I prioritized strong regulation, public funding, and privacy protections for biobanking systems.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 48 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 48 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 48 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. There is a lot of consultation by govt – but who is listening?  And what power do they have to make changes?
2. A lot of people may be politically ignorant, but they believe what they see and hear on television, and that makes them vote the way they do. They have been brainwashed by the clever advertising people.
3. Democracy is a term which has lost much of its original meaning.
4. If you want your vote to count for anything, then you need to not vote in ignorance, you need to know something about what you're being offered.
5. The true believers are about decency in life, about a capacity to debate the issues and to receive different views.
6. Republicanism is a smokescreen for democratic treachery, incompetence and lunacy.
7. We should not be afraid of disagreement. Indeed, an important feature of a liberal democracy is respect for conflicting ideas; difference is part of the human condition. 
8. The true function of government is to maintain peace and justice. This does not include interfering in private transactions of its electors.
9. People get the government they deserve
10. I'm always cynical about government processes.
11. Sometimes I get a bit worried that there's a lot of small minority groups that tend to get a lot of the say
12. Governments can talk a great game about 'democracy'. They fall down, in practice, because they cannot accept any sharing of the power to influence decisions with those who might have different motives and ideas.
13. We as individuals have a right, that's what democracy means to me
14. I don't want to be in a place where only a minority's viewpoint gets the right to say what's going to happen.
15. We should strengthen protections of the free press in order to facilitate a more open and publicly accountable government. 
16. Democracy means that all policy is exposed to open discussion and debate in a public political space of all citizens before being put to a transparent, accountable vote.
17. The only time we are all equal is when we vote in the ballot box.
18. The fundamental dynamic of Australian society is that it is one of evolution, not revolution.
19. Until women are equally represented in Australian parliaments, we will not have a genuine representative democracy.
20. If Australia is to recover from the horrible mess we are in at present, we will need leaders of high principles, who will govern with honesty, justice, and righteousness, fearlessly putting into practice the principles of the Bible.
21. We live in a great democracy.
22. We suffer a Parliamentary Democracy and an archaic and conflict oriented, "two party system" where one of two main parties will manipulate us for the next few years. 
23. Democracy means we, the people, are responsible for what government does, or fails to do.
24. Low female participation rates compound the domination of the public realm by males.
25. I don't know too much about democracy. I feel ridiculous voting.
26. Too few people have a lot of sway in the system.  Corporate lobbyists, vested interests, pork barrelling and contributions to political parties are all problematic.
27. You don't have to wait three years to say 'I'm not happy with the job you did.' You can apply pressure, and enough people writing to the local member can turn the situation around.
28. In the Senate there should be elected representatives who are not from the major parties but from smaller interest groups.
29. I don't think we have a lot of input into legislation and a lot of things that are important.
30. The party system is the main obstruction to accountable politics.
31. People are quite capable of processing and thinking about the vast majority of issues facing our society but as long as we are subjected to 'news lite' the level of political debate will remain facile. 
32. Our political system's strength is that it can change to meet changing circumstances.
33. Our government is attempting to mould our society to the needs of a profit-oriented market
34. There's a dollar democracy that runs through our supposed democracy.
35. It would be a great thing if voters could vote on specific issues, not only on a whole party program at election time.
36. I suppose we do have an upper class and a lower class.
37. The people we elect are loyal not to we dumb bunnies who elected them, but the agenda and dogma of their party. 
38. Free markets work because individual people, cooperating peacefully and voluntarily through markets, can achieve much that politicians and bureaucrats cannot achieve using compulsion and direction.
39. Proportional Representation also forces parties to coalesce and moderates out the extreme political views. 
40. The political system is remote and closed and the connection with elected representatives is difficult, they are often faceless.
41. In Australia the rich have virtually unlimited access to the legal system and the capacity to use it to achieve their own ends.
42. We are a democratic country.
43. I don't think there's anything wrong with people voting for their self-interest.
44. The last thing we need is a Canberra 'Big Brother' telling us what we should read and hear.
45. Our community and nation should invoke a spirit that you are important, that you do have a way of influencing things.
46. Not voting is a form of expression. It's a way of telling parties that no one is offering policies that appeal to you.
47. Concluding that some races/cultures are better than others must be avoided.
48. There is no real difference in ideological terms between the major parties and preference distributions are problematic.

15. The people we elect are loyal not to we dumb bunnies who elected them, but the agenda and dogma of their party. 
16. It would be a great thing if voters could vote on specific issues, not only on a whole party program at election time.

32. We should strengthen protections of the free press in order to facilitate a more open and publicly accountable government. 
33. The political system is remote and closed and the connection with elected representatives is difficult, they are often faceless.

36. Until women are equally represented in Australian parliaments, we will not have a genuine representative democracy.
37. Democracy is a term which has lost much of its original meaning.
38. In the Senate there should be elected representatives who are not from the major parties but from smaller interest groups.
39. Our political system's strength is that it can change to meet changing circumstances.
40. There's a dollar democracy that runs through our supposed democracy.

47. We should not be afraid of disagreement. Indeed, an important feature of a liberal democracy is respect for conflicting ideas; difference is part of the human condition.

## Instructions:

- In your response, return an ordered list of 33 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. It is clear that we are already entering the zone of dangerous climate change.
2. We need strong political leadership to do something about climate change.
3. Climate variation is normal, so why should this be a problem?
4. I care about the planet.
5. The response to  climate change is not going to be positive.  The same mistakes will keep happening.
6. I believe that the difference we can have as an individual, in Australia, is so minimal that our actions are worthless.
7. I don't trust what I hear about climate change from government.
8. The fate of the planet is too important to be left to market forces.
9. We can adapt to the coming changes.
10. There is not enough information to definitively say that climate change is real.
11. We should pay for greenhouse emissions.
12. Failure to address climate change is the fault of political leaders.
13. I don't know what to do. I'm very concerned and would like to do something, but I don't have a realistic shortlist of things that would really make a difference.
14. Australia does not owe it to the rest of the world to reduce emissions and suffer economically.
15. Governments should take a far greater role in preparing towns and cities to adapt to the impacts of climate change.
16. Doing something to reduce emissions feels a bit hopeless but I just want to feel that I'm doing the most I can.
17. I think it is safe to say climate change is here.
18. This is so depressing and is so out of our control.
19. More educational programmes are needed to increase public awareness about climate change.
20. If Australia reduces greenhouse gases it won't make a difference. That will just shift Australian jobs to other countries. 
21. It is unfair that we are going to leave the climate in a mess for future generations.
22. It is already too late to do anything, as any action to stop climate change will take a long time to take effect.
23. Climate change will not be a problem because there will be technological solutions available.
24. I don't trust what scientists say about climate change.
25. I'm not going to do anything to address climate change because it is not a major issue.
26. It's difficult to trust what comes out in the media on the issue of climate change.
27. There's not much point in me doing anything to fix this. No-one else is going to.
28. Australia is particularly vulnerable to climate change, and it is in our interest to help find an effective global solution.
29. When I read in the paper that climate change is not true, I start to have doubts about whether it is changing.
30. We need laws addressing climate change because people are not going to volunteer to change.
31. I want to do something, but it is too big and too hard.
32. Australia's emissions are tiny, so it's not up to us to act.
33. I'm not concerned enough to do anything drastic about this, such as participate in political action.

## Instructions:

## [Example output]:

2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Preparing for climate risk through the development of new approaches and technologies that enhance resilience to the impacts of climate variability or change. 
2. Policies that involve a dramatic cut back in CO2 emissions (by 50% in the next 10 years).
3. Leave the policy settings as they are.
4. Adaptation policies and expenditure (e.g. coastal protection, water desalinisation, improving infrastructure etc). Planning controls and emergency response programs.
5. Policies that emphasise economic growth over climate change adaptation or mitigation.
6. Adaptation policies that target individual, small business or community-based actions (eg support the installation of alternative energy generators, insulation, water use efficiency)
7. Policies that involve a moderate cut in CO2 emissions (by 25% in over the next 10 years).

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Prioritize resilience and adaptation, balance emissions cuts with growth, avoid inaction or denial.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 45 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 45 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 45 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Fire risk reduction projects should clearly focus on the wildland-urban interface, avoiding treatments in roadless areas.
2. We have to move forward with large-scale restoration-based fuel reduction and learn as we go.
3. If an action is determined to be necessary to control a wildfire, save lives and/or property, and ensure that fire crews can do their jobs safely and efficiently, then it is appropriate to act even if it results in the take of an endangered species.
4. Forests must contribute to the economic stability of forest-dependent communities.  There are many job opportunities and value-added products that come out of the forest such as wood for art, vigas for building homes, wildlife for food, herbs for medicine, and grass for livestock.
5. Land managers should return public forest land to natural conditions and fire cycles that are specific to each forest-type.
6. Traditional, sustainable forestry that benefits local economies and maintains rural livelihoods is much better than large scale corporate forestry.
7. Prescribed burning is needed to restore fire-adapted ecosystems.
8. People should take what is needed from forests, but in a context of stewardship and sustainable use and interaction with nature. 
9. Fire is a natural and vital component of most western forest ecosystems.
10. Old Growth protection is necessary in order to preserve and protect the viability of species dependent upon Old Growth ecosystems.
11. Without public participation there will be conflict, whereas participation leads to cooperation.
12. All fuels treatment projects on public lands should comply with existing environmental laws even if compliance slows implementation.
13. To make thinning projects cost effective, private logging companies must be able to log larger trees.
14. Large trees must be removed in order to create openings for wildlife habitat. 
15. Environmental organizations have moved the management of our forests to where it is being done by emotion and not by science.
16. Needless red tape and lawsuits delay effective implementation of forest health projects on public lands.
17. Using citizen participation in forest management is very important for basing decisions on different ideas and cultural values along with science. 
18. Forest health means jobs.
19. Science is the most important component informing all management decisions — more so than social, cultural and economic considerations.
20. We should not manipulate nature by restoring forest conditions.
21. Humans are a part of the environment. We need to learn how to live sustainably with that environment as much as possible. 
22. Forest restoration projects should be done in all areas of the forest including roadless and wilderness areas.
23. Returning forests to presettlement conditions ignores the need for wildlife that are adapted to current forest conditions by mandating drastic thinning virtually overnight. 
24. Aggressive fire suppression has caused the majority of the problems regarding  fires. 
25. Federal land management procedures are so complex that they prevent timely action to address ecological crises on public lands.
26. Forest health needs restoring after decades of government mismanagement.
27. We need to be cautious: the solution is there, but we still have a lot to learn. If we just jump in, we're going to make mistakes.
28. We need active forest management on our public lands, through thinning and prescribed burns to reduce the unnatural buildup of fuels.
29. Federal forest management policy should make it easier for loggers to thin out backcountry forests by easing regulatory restrictions and making it harder for interest groups to stop or delay that work.
30. Demonizing fire is a mistake: we must accept risks of fire damage to property and implement controlled burning.
31. The government is advancing timber sales in the name of ecological restoration.
32. Federal agencies need to restore public trust through transparency in project intent, development and implementation.
33. We need to experiment with a range of treatments that could meet restoration goals. 
34. The main issue in forest management is to protect loss of life and property due to catastrophic wildfire. 
35. Prescribed burns are a flawed idea, especially when there are other practices available for restoration.
36. Forest management involves restoring ecosystem function and processes that maintain ecosystems over the long run. 
37. We need to clean up the bureaucratic maze that stops our professional foresters from being able to do the work that they are trained to do.
38. Small scale thinning projects should give the communities involved pride in taking part in a sustainable forest management plan, and it also allows the traditional communities to realize a boost to their fragile economies.
39. Natural resources must be developed for the benefit of the plain American citizen.
40. Forest lands should be brought back to their state before human intervention began.
41. Thinning efforts should focus entirely on the small trees that make up the vast majority of the fire risk in the forest. 
42. A diameter cap should be placed on all thinning projects to ensure large trees are not cut.
43. We need to allow forest managers to determine how to improve forest health to minimize fire damage and loss.
44. The increased density of forests in the West has not damaged ecosystems.
45. Stakeholders in forest management should work together to define management objectives more by experiments and adaptive management.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.

## [Example output]:

2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Management that favors the protection of wildlife and wildlife habitat.
2. Management that favors local-based harvesting for fuel and timber needs.
3. Management that favors aggressive reduction of hazardous fuels
4. Management that favors treatments to restore structure, function and composition of the forest to presettlement conditions, and allowing the introduction of fire as a natural disturbance.
5. Management that prioritizes the location and level of treatments favoring both ecological and social values (i.e. wildlife, watersheds, community protection, special cultural places).
6. Management that favors thinning treatments to realize economic gain.
7. No fire or fuels management. Leaving the forests as they stand without active management.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: I prioritized ecological restoration and community protection while balancing social and economic needs.

1. We need to be cautious: the solution is there, but we still have a lot to learn. If we just jump in, we're going to make mistakes.
2. Land managers should return public forest land to natural conditions and fire cycles that are specific to each forest-type.
3. Forest health means jobs.
4. Federal agencies need to restore public trust through transparency in project intent, development and implementation.
5. Federal forest management policy should make it easier for loggers to thin out backcountry forests by easing regulatory restrictions and making it harder for interest groups to stop or delay that work.
6. Old Growth protection is necessary in order to preserve and protect the viability of species dependent upon Old Growth ecosystems.
7. Forest lands should be brought back to their state before human intervention began.
8. Thinning efforts should focus entirely on the small trees that make up the vast majority of the fire risk in the forest. 
9. A diameter cap should be placed on all thinning projects to ensure large trees are not cut.
10. Prescribed burns are a flawed idea, especially when there are other practices available for restoration.
11. Forest restoration projects should be done in all areas of the forest including roadless and wilderness areas.
12. Science is the most important component informing all management decisions — more so than social, cultural and economic considerations.
13. If an action is determined to be necessary to control a wildfire, save lives and/or property, and ensure that fire crews can do their jobs safely and efficiently, then it is appropriate to act even if it results in the take of an endangered species.
14. To make thinning projects cost effective, private logging companies must be able to log larger trees.
15. Without public participation there will be conflict, whereas participation leads to cooperation.
16. Humans are a part of the environment. We need to learn how to live sustainably with that environment as much as possible. 
17. Needless red tape and lawsuits delay effective implementation of forest health projects on public lands.
18. We need to allow forest managers to determine how to improve forest health to minimize fire damage and loss.
19. Fire is a natural and vital component of most western forest ecosystems.
20. Fire risk reduction projects should clearly focus on the wildland-urban interface, avoiding treatments in roadless areas.
21. Federal land management procedures are so complex that they prevent timely action to address ecological crises on public lands.
22. Prescribed burning is needed to restore fire-adapted ecosystems.
23. We need to clean up the bureaucratic maze that stops our professional foresters from being able to do the work that they are trained to do.
24. Natural resources must be developed for the benefit of the plain American citizen.
25. The main issue in forest management is to protect loss of life and property due to catastrophic wildfire. 
26. Aggressive fire suppression has caused the majority of the problems regarding  fires. 
27. We have to move forward with large-scale restoration-based fuel reduction and learn as we go.
28. Environmental organizations have moved the management of our forests to where it is being done by emotion and not by science.
29. Large trees must be removed in order to create openings for wildlife habitat. 
30. We need active forest management on our public lands, through thinning and prescribed burns to reduce the unnatural buildup of fuels.
31. Small scale thinning projects should give the communities involved pride in taking part in a sustainable forest management plan, and it also allows the traditional communities to realize a boost to their fragile economies.
32. The government is advancing timber sales in the name of ecological restoration.
33. Returning forests to presettlement conditions ignores the need for wildlife that are adapted to current forest conditions by mandating drastic thinning virtually overnight. 
34. Forests must contribute to the economic stability of forest-dependent communities.  There are many job opportunities and value-added products that come out of the forest such as wood for art, vigas for building homes, wildlife for food, herbs for medicine, and grass for livestock.

36. We need to experiment with a range of treatments that could meet restoration goals. 
37. Stakeholders in forest management should work together to define management objectives more by experiments and adaptive management. 
38. Traditional, sustainable forestry that benefits local economies and maintains rural livelihoods is much better than large scale corporate forestry.
39. People should take what is needed from forests, but in a context of stewardship and sustainable use and interaction with nature. 
40. The increased density of forests in the West has not damaged ecosystems.
41. Demonizing fire is a mistake: we must accept risks of fire damage to property and implement controlled burning.
42. Using citizen participation in forest management is very important for basing decisions on different ideas and cultural values along with science. 
43. All fuels treatment projects on public lands should comply with existing environmental laws even if compliance slows implementation.
44. Forest management involves restoring ecosystem function and processes that maintain ecosystems over the long run. 
45. We should not manipulate nature by restoring forest conditions.

## Instructions:

4. Management that favors the protection of wildlife and wildlife habitat.
5. Management that favors local-based harvesting for fuel and timber needs.
6. Management that favors treatments to restore structure, function and composition of the forest to presettlement conditions, and allowing the introduction of fire as a natural disturbance.
7. Management that favors thinning treatments to realize economic gain.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Balanced management prioritizing ecology, community protection and wildlife over economics is ideal.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 45 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 45 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 45 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. We have to move forward with large-scale restoration-based fuel reduction and learn as we go.
2. We need to allow forest managers to determine how to improve forest health to minimize fire damage and loss.
3. Needless red tape and lawsuits delay effective implementation of forest health projects on public lands.
4. Thinning efforts should focus entirely on the small trees that make up the vast majority of the fire risk in the forest. 
5. Traditional, sustainable forestry that benefits local economies and maintains rural livelihoods is much better than large scale corporate forestry.
6. We need to clean up the bureaucratic maze that stops our professional foresters from being able to do the work that they are trained to do.
7. Forests must contribute to the economic stability of forest-dependent communities.  There are many job opportunities and value-added products that come out of the forest such as wood for art, vigas for building homes, wildlife for food, herbs for medicine, and grass for livestock.
8. To make thinning projects cost effective, private logging companies must be able to log larger trees.
9. Humans are a part of the environment. We need to learn how to live sustainably with that environment as much as possible. 
10. Large trees must be removed in order to create openings for wildlife habitat. 
11. Aggressive fire suppression has caused the majority of the problems regarding  fires. 
12. Environmental organizations have moved the management of our forests to where it is being done by emotion and not by science.
13. Science is the most important component informing all management decisions — more so than social, cultural and economic considerations.
14. Forest health means jobs.
15. Federal land management procedures are so complex that they prevent timely action to address ecological crises on public lands.
16. Using citizen participation in forest management is very important for basing decisions on different ideas and cultural values along with science. 
17. If an action is determined to be necessary to control a wildfire, save lives and/or property, and ensure that fire crews can do their jobs safely and efficiently, then it is appropriate to act even if it results in the take of an endangered species.
18. Fire risk reduction projects should clearly focus on the wildland-urban interface, avoiding treatments in roadless areas.
19. People should take what is needed from forests, but in a context of stewardship and sustainable use and interaction with nature. 
20. Forest lands should be brought back to their state before human intervention began.
21. Federal forest management policy should make it easier for loggers to thin out backcountry forests by easing regulatory restrictions and making it harder for interest groups to stop or delay that work.
22. Demonizing fire is a mistake: we must accept risks of fire damage to property and implement controlled burning.
23. All fuels treatment projects on public lands should comply with existing environmental laws even if compliance slows implementation.
24. A diameter cap should be placed on all thinning projects to ensure large trees are not cut.
25. We need to be cautious: the solution is there, but we still have a lot to learn. If we just jump in, we're going to make mistakes.
26. The increased density of forests in the West has not damaged ecosystems.
27. Forest management involves restoring ecosystem function and processes that maintain ecosystems over the long run. 
28. The government is advancing timber sales in the name of ecological restoration.
29. Without public participation there will be conflict, whereas participation leads to cooperation.
30. Old Growth protection is necessary in order to preserve and protect the viability of species dependent upon Old Growth ecosystems.
31. Prescribed burning is needed to restore fire-adapted ecosystems.
32. Stakeholders in forest management should work together to define management objectives more by experiments and adaptive management. 
33. Fire is a natural and vital component of most western forest ecosystems.
34. The main issue in forest management is to protect loss of life and property due to catastrophic wildfire. 
35. Forest health needs restoring after decades of government mismanagement.
36. Prescribed burns are a flawed idea, especially when there are other practices available for restoration.
37. We need active forest management on our public lands, through thinning and prescribed burns to reduce the unnatural buildup of fuels.
38. We should not manipulate nature by restoring forest conditions.
39. We need to experiment with a range of treatments that could meet restoration goals. 
40. Federal agencies need to restore public trust through transparency in project intent, development and implementation.
41. Small scale thinning projects should give the communities involved pride in taking part in a sustainable forest management plan, and it also allows the traditional communities to realize a boost to their fragile economies.
42. Natural resources must be developed for the benefit of the plain American citizen.
43. Land managers should return public forest land to natural conditions and fire cycles that are specific to each forest-type.
44. Returning forests to presettlement conditions ignores the need for wildlife that are adapted to current forest conditions by mandating drastic thinning virtually overnight. 
45. Forest restoration projects should be done in all areas of the forest including roadless and wilderness areas.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 38 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 38 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 38 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. It is always permissible to do research on my personally identifiable sample without my prior permission.  
2. Participants who donate their samples for research should be given special access to the treatments and therapies that result from that research. 
3. Genetic information is different from health information. 
4. Participants should be contacted every time researchers want to use their samples for research.
5. Public funds should pay for biobanks, instead of private companies.  
6. Deciding how to regulate biobanks should be left to the government. 
7. If someone is a carrier of a genetic disease, they have a responsibility to participate in genetic research.
8. Biobanks are useful even if they only produce more scientific knowledge and not medical advancements.
9. There is no point in consulting the public about ethical issues in science and technology.
10. Aboriginal communities require special consideration concerning healthcare and research.
11. Policy makers should consider the possibility that Canada should not pursue biobanking.
12. There is no risk to the participants who donate to biobanks.
13. Participants should always be able to withdraw their sample from research at anytime. 
14. Race is a useful topic for genetic studies.
15. The community that donates samples for research should receive improved medical services.  
16. I trust researchers to control access to my personal samples.
17. Genetic research will improve our lives.
18. Educating people about health issues (e.g. diet and lifestyle changes) promises greater health effects than investing in biobanks.
19. I should have property rights to my tissues before or after they leave my body.
20. Biobanks need independent review boards to determine who should have access to samples. 
21. Scientists should have access to all unidentified, personal samples for research.
22. The priority for healthcare should be to reduce inequalities and the burden of disease.
23. Sampling some people in an ethnocultural community is acceptable only if the whole ethnocultural community has agreed to participate.
24. Everyone should donate samples to a biobank for the benefit of everyone. 
25. I do not care if my donated sample is connected to my name and medical information.
26. All participants should be paid for donating their samples to a biobank. 
27. High-priced genetic research is diverting funds that could be used to promote public health.
28. Permission from the indigenous community must be sought if samples are collected from indigenous peoples.
29. The confidentiality of personal medical information is critical in any circumstance where research is being conducted.
30. Biobanks will only lead to expensive treatments and high profits. 
31. Researchers should be allowed to use samples for research but they should not own them.  
32. Participants should be active in the set up and oversight of  biobanks. 
33. The fact that we cannot predict what biobanks will be used for bothers me. 
34. Genetic studies of disability will lead to the discrimination of people living with the same conditions.
35. To me, religious communities need to be consulted about genetic and biobank research. 
36. Profits from biobanking should be returned to the donating community. 
37. Genetic studies of race on enthocultural communities will lead to the discrimination of those same enthocultural communities. 
38. My personal sample should never be anonymized since I should be informed of important research results.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 7 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 7 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Every use of stored data and biological samples for research requires the authorization of individuals, even if the use does not identify the individual.
2. Use of stored data and biological samples for research requires authorization from individuals ONLY when the individual is identifiable.
3. Regardless of privacy and oversight, it is most important to prevent discrimination (e.g., through insurance, social attitudes) that might result from research on collections of data and biological samples.
4. Use of stored data and biological samples for research requires approval by an appropriate governing body (e.g., research ethics board), regardless of whether the individual is identifiable.
5. Regardless of privacy and oversight, it is most important to ensure benefits to society or the community (e.g., geographical, ethno-cultural) participating in a collection of data and biological samples.
6. Use of stored data and biological samples for research requires authorization from individuals only when they are identifiable AND approval by an appropriate governing body (e.g. research ethics board) when they are not identifiable.
7. Use of stored data and biological samples for research requires approval by an appropriate governing body (e.g., research ethics board), ONLY when the individual is identifiable.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Prioritized oversight, privacy protection, and societal benefits while minimizing barriers to research.

- In your response, return an ordered list of 38 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 38 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Participants who donate their samples for research should be given special access to the treatments and therapies that result from that research. 
2. I do not care if my donated sample is connected to my name and medical information.
3. It is always permissible to do research on my personally identifiable sample without my prior permission.  
4. Genetic studies of disability will lead to the discrimination of people living with the same conditions.
5. Participants should always be able to withdraw their sample from research at anytime. 
6. Genetic research will improve our lives.
7. Genetic information is different from health information. 
8. The confidentiality of personal medical information is critical in any circumstance where research is being conducted.
9. Deciding how to regulate biobanks should be left to the government. 
10. Aboriginal communities require special consideration concerning healthcare and research.
11. Race is a useful topic for genetic studies.
12. Researchers should be allowed to use samples for research but they should not own them.  
13. Biobanks will only lead to expensive treatments and high profits. 
14. Educating people about health issues (e.g. diet and lifestyle changes) promises greater health effects than investing in biobanks.
15. Profits from biobanking should be returned to the donating community. 
16. Genetic studies of race on enthocultural communities will lead to the discrimination of those same enthocultural communities. 
17. There is no point in consulting the public about ethical issues in science and technology.
18. Sampling some people in an ethnocultural community is acceptable only if the whole ethnocultural community has agreed to participate.
19. Participants should be contacted every time researchers want to use their samples for research.
20. The fact that we cannot predict what biobanks will be used for bothers me. 
21. The community that donates samples for research should receive improved medical services.  
22. There is no risk to the participants who donate to biobanks.
23. Public funds should pay for biobanks, instead of private companies.  
24. I should have property rights to my tissues before or after they leave my body.
25. To me, religious communities need to be consulted about genetic and biobank research. 
26. My personal sample should never be anonymized since I should be informed of important research results.  
27. High-priced genetic research is diverting funds that could be used to promote public health.
28. Everyone should donate samples to a biobank for the benefit of everyone. 
29. Biobanks need independent review boards to determine who should have access to samples. 
30. The priority for healthcare should be to reduce inequalities and the burden of disease.
31. Participants should be active in the set up and oversight of  biobanks. 
32. Policy makers should consider the possibility that Canada should not pursue biobanking.
33. If someone is a carrier of a genetic disease, they have a responsibility to participate in genetic research.
34. Scientists should have access to all unidentified, personal samples for research.
35. Permission from the indigenous community must be sought if samples are collected from indigenous peoples.
36. Biobanks are useful even if they only produce more scientific knowledge and not medical advancements.
37. All participants should be paid for donating their samples to a biobank. 
38. I trust researchers to control access to my personal samples.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 7 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 7 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Use of stored data and biological samples for research requires approval by an appropriate governing body (e.g., research ethics board), regardless of whether the individual is identifiable.
2. Use of stored data and biological samples for research requires approval by an appropriate governing body (e.g., research ethics board), ONLY when the individual is identifiable.
3. Use of stored data and biological samples for research requires authorization from individuals ONLY when the individual is identifiable.
4. Every use of stored data and biological samples for research requires the authorization of individuals, even if the use does not identify the individual.
5. Regardless of privacy and oversight, it is most important to ensure benefits to society or the community (e.g., geographical, ethno-cultural) participating in a collection of data and biological samples.
6. Use of stored data and biological samples for research requires authorization from individuals only when they are identifiable AND approval by an appropriate governing body (e.g. research ethics board) when they are not identifiable.
7. Regardless of privacy and oversight, it is most important to prevent discrimination (e.g., through insurance, social attitudes) that might result from research on collections of data and biological samples.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Prioritize oversight, limit individual authorization, balance societal benefit and discrimination risk.

- In your response, return an ordered list of 31 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].

## [Example output]:

2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Health services need to prepare for the physical impacts of climate change on health (such as heat stroke) and the impacts on mental health (such as farmers who lose their crops).
2. We need to make sure we have a good local response for disasters to deal with extreme weather.
3. It's difficult to trust what comes out in the media on the issue of climate change.
4. If Switzerland reduces greenhouse gases it won't make a difference.
5. The climate threat to the Alpine glaciers is too far away from local issues to be of concern.
6. Planning for climate adaptation needs a holistic approach, considering a whole range of issues, instead of focussing on individual issues. 
7. We need (local) funding to boost our emergency response for events such as flooding.
8. The main focus of planning for climate adaptation should be to prepare for extreme weather events, such as drought and flooding. 
9. Doing something to reduce emissions feels a bit hopeless but I just want to feel that I'm doing the most I can.
10. We need to deal with the urban heat island effect through measures such as planting trees.
11. We should focus on protecting human systems rather than environmental ecosystems.
12. It is important to plan for migration by people displaced by climate impacts.
13. I think it is safe to say climate change is here.
14. There is not enough information to definitively say that climate change is real.
15. Increased costs for insurance are a serious concern in respect to climate change.
16. Climate variation is normal, so why should this be a problem?
17. Councils have all the resources they need to adapt effectively to climate change.
18. I don't trust what I hear about climate change from government.
19. I believe that the difference we can have as an individual, in Switzerland, is so minimal that our actions are worthless.
20. There's not much point in me doing anything to fix this. No-one else is going to.
21. Occorre tenere conto degli effetti negativi del cambiamento climatico sul commercio locale.
22. I'm not going to do anything to address climate change because it is not a major issue.
23. It is NOT necessary to engage with the community when deciding what are the most important issues for planning for climate adaptation.
24. I don't trust what scientists say about climate change.
25. There is no urgent need to prepare for an increase in illness and death caused by high temperatures.
26. I don't know what to do. I'm very concerned and would like to do something, but I don't have a realistic shortlist of things that would really make a difference.
27. Some communities will be more affected than others by climate change, but this is not a priority issue. 
28. It is important to support vulnerable groups (elderly, children, disabled, low-income) as they have the fewest resources to deal with impacts of climate change. 
29. Switzerland is particularly vulnerable to climate change, and it is in our interest to help find an effective global solution.
30. The community should be involved in discussions about climate adaptation.
31. We need to focus on adaptation actions that are concerned with the economic future of the country.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 7 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 7 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Adaptation policies and expenditure. Planning controls and emergency response programs.
2. Preparing for climate risk through the development of new approaches and technologies that enhance resilience to the impacts of climate variability or change.
3. Policies that involve a moderate cut in CO2 emissions (at least 25% in over the next 10 years).
4. Policies that involve a dramatic cut back in CO2 emissions (at least 50% in the next 10 years).
5. Leave the policy settings as they are.
6. Policies that emphasise economic growth over climate change adaptation or mitigation.
7. Adaptation policies that target individual, small business or community-based actions (e.g., support the installation of alternative energy generators, insulation, water use efficiency)

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Prioritize resilience and adaptation, followed by significant emissions cuts, over economic growth.

8. Farmers should be encouraged to practice ecologically sustainable agriculture, such as permaculture.

15. Products that employ products that damage the environment, such as palm oil, should be taxed in a similar fashion to tobacco products
16. Food that is NOT environmentally-sustainable, healthy and fairly-produced should be clearly labelled
17. Switzerland already has some of the toughest regulations about protecting our environment and agriculture
18. Climate variation is normal, so why should this be a problem?
19. Biodiversity is at risk due to the use of pesticides and monoculture farming
20. The government should ensure that farmers are paid fair prices for their produce to secure higher incomes for those working in agriculture
21. To give subsidies only to farmers who do not use pesticides is an "extreme" approach that would mean falling crop yields and higher food prices
22. I don't care where the product I am buying comes from.
23. Restaurants in schools or retirement homes should only offer vegetarian menus.
24. Food waste is a major environmental issue
25. Climate warming will ultimately benefit food production globally as plants better growth in higher temperature
26. If Switzerland implements strong regulations on importing environmentally-sustainable and fairly-produced food, we would either have to step out of our international trade agreements or have to renegotiate most of them
27. The government should apply costum duties on imported products that can be produced in Switzerland (e.g., cheese, honey, apples, beef)
28. Intensive animal farming and monocultural plantation guarantees food supply
29. Subsidies should only be given to farmers that do not use pesticides or antibiotics
30. I am happy to change my nutrition habits, as use leftovers in future meals, if this helps to prevent food waste

- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 6 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 6, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 6 the option you support the least.

1. Leave the policy settings as they are.
2. Political measures that create incentives for local producers to produce sustainable foods (e.g., subsidies or tax breaks for local farmers who produce organic products).
3. Political measures that focus on less regulation  (e.g., policies that promote free trade agreements by reducing food regulations)
4. Political measures aimed at investing in research to develop sustainable agricultural techniques or materials.

6. Political measures that include radical regulation toward sustainable food production (e.g., banning all pesticides, banning the import of foods produced using unsustainable methods).

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: I favor moderate regulation and incentives for sustainable local food production over extreme policies.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 20 [Considerations] below from 1 to 7, where 1 is strongly disagree and 7 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 20 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 20 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Investing in mental health services in schools and workplaces (for example, having social workers in facilities) is essential to prevent negative mental health outcomes.
2. Mental health can be understood in different ways. A comprehensive definition of mental health should take into account social issues such as poverty, inequality, and discrimination.
3. More government funding is needed to improve mental health services and their accessibility, especially for marginalized people subject to socioeconomic disparities.
4. Minors under the age of 16 should be legally prohibited from using social media.
5. Personal solutions (such as joining a yoga club) are more effective than government intervention in addressing mental health issues (such as having social workers or psychologists in schools).
6. Personal cultural or religious beliefs and preferences should guide the choice of treatment methods, including therapy and medication.
7. Being poor, living far from urban centers, or being a victim of racism are examples of factors that can influence a person's willingness to seek help for mental health problems.
8. Individuals should take responsibility for their own mental well-being.
9. To prevent people with mental health issues from feeling lonely or isolated, we should talk more about these topics in schools and workplaces to increase public understanding and sensitivity.
10. Schools should play a crucial role in creating a supportive environment, both online and offline, to mitigate the negative impact of social media on mental health.
11. It is good that basic health insurance does not fully cover mental health care since only a few people need it.
12. Mental health problems are solely medical in nature and not a social issue.
13. People should take responsibility for actively addressing their own biases and prejudices against individuals with mental health disorders.
14. Social media contribute to mental health issues through cyberbullying, social comparison, and unrealistic portrayals of life.
15. Focusing on prevention strategies (e.g., government media campaigns) is essential to reducing the impact of stigma associated with mental health conditions.
16. Social media platforms should be required to have parental controls.
17. Private mental health services are better than public ones, so Switzerland's mental health system should be entirely privatized.
18. Mental health issues require less urgency and fewer resources compared to physical health conditions.
19. Improving working or study conditions does not impact people's mental health in any way.
20. People with mental disorders should not be allowed to work with children.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.

- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

1. There are too many mental health services in Switzerland, and they should be reduced.
2. There should be more integrated mental health clinics that provide a range of services, such as sports or artistic activities in addition to therapy and medication
3. There are enough mental health services in Switzerland, and funding should remain as it is.
4. Private mental health clinics should receive more government funding to allow more people to access them.
5. There should be more public awareness campaigns that empower people to seek mental health support and destigmatize help-seeking behaviors.
6. Initiatives focused on improving the socioeconomic conditions of disadvantaged people should be implemented to address mental health disparities.
7. There are not enough mental health services in Switzerland, so their funding should be increased.

- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.

response: I prioritized addressing socioeconomic disparities and increasing access to integrated services.

1. “Intensive food production can go along with the protection of the environment and health”
2. Sustainable agriculture increases prices and harms consumer freedom. The production should be adapted to what people demand.
3. Products that use environmentally harmful ingredients, such as palm oil, should be taxed in the same way as tobacco products.
4. We need actions to protect inhabitants and the biodiversity from harmful pesticide.
5. There is no urgent need to prepare for an increase in illness and death caused by intensive use of pesticides/antibiotics
6. Agriculture is already very sustainable. Swiss farmers are on the right track
7. It's difficult to trust what comes out in the media on the issue of climate change.
8. I believe that the difference we can have as an individual, in Switzerland, is so minimal that our actions are worthless.
9. The community should be involved in discussions about food system adaptation.
10. “Actions on the food system in Switzerland will lead to increased imports and shift of the pollution abroad”
11. The Swiss food system depends on imports from other countries, and it is in our interest to help find an effective global solution.
12. I think it is safe to say climate change is here.
13. “Farmers already suffer enough from strict rules and paperwork. Family farmers should have more liberties”
14. We should focus on protecting human systems rather than environmental ecosystems.
15. “Food accessibility (price) and security (availability) is NOT COMPATIBLE with a sustainable food system”
16. Agricultural subsidies should promote sustainable, pesticide and antibiotic-free production.
17. As long as we use animals in agriculture, it cannot be sustainable

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 45 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 45 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 45 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Can we be confident, that if we store CO2 the storage facility is going to hold it forever? That's really the issue. And I don't think anybody can answer that question.
2. The limited strategic and technical insight that is so entrenched in Australia is limiting the development of innovative energy technologies.
3. Climate change considerations have no role in the development of national and global energy policies.
4. Combining technologies in the energy sector is a much more promising and more productive approach than relying on a single approach. 
5. I'm not pro-nuclear, I'm not pro-coal, I'm not pro-wind, I'm not pro any kind of generation. I'm pro-energy conservation through changes to our behavioural and design practices.
6. I don't want the implementation of new energy technologies to disrupt my way of life.
7. Natural gas is the bridging fuel between the oil economy and the hydrogen economy.
8. Any return on geosequestration is 15 to 20 years off, whereas the proven technology of renewable energy offers immediate gains.
9. Australia should  turn more attention to biomass energy sources because it is CO2 neutral (the carbon dioxide used by the growing plants is released when they are burned).
10. Solar power is pointless because it can't guarantee constant supply, for obvious reasons: the sun doesn't always shine.
11. The petroleum age is far from over, we will still be able to keep finding more oil.
12. Energy is going to get costly so we had better start investing in alternatives.
13. Nuclear has a few dangers, but they're trivial compared with the dangers of emitting greenhouse gases and letting global warming happen.
14. Wind power has its downsides — it is highly visible and can kill birds. The fact is though, that any man-made structure can kill birds.	
15. Nuclear is the inevitable replacement for old hydrocarbon technology. It is cost-competitive with coal and will cogenerate potable water and hydrogen also at societally acceptable costs.
16. Local energy solutions such as windfarms are good for jobs, local economies and tourism.
17. It is very hard to trust all these so-called experts arguing for one energy technology or another, especially when they, or their bosses, are just in it to make money.
18. Coal-powered energy needs to be minimised because of its high greenhouse gas emissions.
19. We need coal because it is a cheap and reliable energy source.
20. Reducing our reliance on oil would be good for the economy and the environment.
21. Renewables are part of the long-term solution, but for the foreseeable future, they just can't do the job.
22. Our present energy system is so cheap precisely because it is unsustainable.
23. There is no need make expensive investments in technological changes within the energy sector.
24. You could have a wind farm across all of the outback that would kill every kookaburra, but it wouldn't provide the baseload power we need.
25. Geothermal or hot rock technology will provide a reliable and unlimited and cheap energy source.
26. Any tax to reduce greenhouse gas emissions will have a detrimental economic effect on the nation.
27. Rather than look at costly renewable energy a more fair-dinkum strategy would be to encourage technology that captures greenhouse emissions like carbon dioxide.
28. Fuzzy-headed thinking about alternative energy sources seems not to appreciate the need for certainty of supply and excess capacity to keep economies growing.
29. Nuclear power is a more proven technology than it was 30 years ago. In reality atomic power generation can be a very safe system if designed and operated correctly.
30. Prices of alternative energy will fall as technology improves.
31. Many big ticket solutions to energy problems that we don't understand are just too risky.
32.  If Australia mines uranium, the country should be able to generate power from it.
33. Using biomass from crops has significant expansion potential and would be good for the rural industry.
34. Renewable sources do not have the potential to meet our future energy needs as they stand.
35. Energy technologies are pretty complex, so I leave it to the experts. 
36. Reducing greenhouse gases should not mean prices have to go up.
37. Apart from coal, natural gas is the only other potentially reliable source of power for the state.
38. If the cost of greenhouse gas emissions is factored in, the cost of renewables compared to coal isn't so big.
39. The urgency of addressing greenhouse emissions cannot stay on back burner for too much longer. So we need to find a solution quickly, such as CO2 capture and storage.
40. Australia spends too much on research and development in energy technologies.
41. Governments must fund new infrastructure investment in the face of uncertainty in the economics of energy technologies.
42. Australia doesn't support alternative energy opportunities. Industry comes along and says, 'Have I got something for you' (such as carbon sequestration, or a new power station) and they get government subsidies to do it.
43. Coal gasification is needed to produce hydrogen on the scale required for a possible transition to a hydrogen-based economy.
44. Energy technologies such as nuclear power and geosequestration are too risky. It's better to improve the technologies that we already have.
45. Environmental, reliability and cost issues will limit the adoption of large-scale  of certain renewable technologies.

1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Prices of alternative energy will fall as technology improves.
2. Energy is going to get costly so we had better start investing in alternatives.
3. Energy technologies such as nuclear power and geosequestration are too risky. It's better to improve the technologies that we already have.
4. Apart from coal, natural gas is the only other potentially reliable source of power for the state.
5. Reducing our reliance on oil would be good for the economy and the environment.
6. Coal-powered energy needs to be minimised because of its high greenhouse gas emissions.
7. Governments must fund new infrastructure investment in the face of uncertainty in the economics of energy technologies.
8. Wind power has its downsides — it is highly visible and can kill birds. The fact is though, that any man-made structure can kill birds.	
9. You could have a wind farm across all of the outback that would kill every kookaburra, but it wouldn't provide the baseload power we need.
10. Australia doesn't support alternative energy opportunities. Industry comes along and says, 'Have I got something for you' (such as carbon sequestration, or a new power station) and they get government subsidies to do it.
11. Reducing greenhouse gases should not mean prices have to go up.
12. If the cost of greenhouse gas emissions is factored in, the cost of renewables compared to coal isn't so big.
13. Any tax to reduce greenhouse gas emissions will have a detrimental economic effect on the nation.
14. The limited strategic and technical insight that is so entrenched in Australia is limiting the development of innovative energy technologies.
15.  If Australia mines uranium, the country should be able to generate power from it.
16. Renewables are part of the long-term solution, but for the foreseeable future, they just can't do the job.
17. Fuzzy-headed thinking about alternative energy sources seems not to appreciate the need for certainty of supply and excess capacity to keep economies growing.
18. Any return on geosequestration is 15 to 20 years off, whereas the proven technology of renewable energy offers immediate gains.
19. Nuclear power is a more proven technology than it was 30 years ago. In reality atomic power generation can be a very safe system if designed and operated correctly.
20. Local energy solutions such as windfarms are good for jobs, local economies and tourism.
21. It is very hard to trust all these so-called experts arguing for one energy technology or another, especially when they, or their bosses, are just in it to make money.
22. Coal gasification is needed to produce hydrogen on the scale required for a possible transition to a hydrogen-based economy.
23. Climate change considerations have no role in the development of national and global energy policies.
24. Using biomass from crops has significant expansion potential and would be good for the rural industry.
25. There is no need make expensive investments in technological changes within the energy sector.
26. Rather than look at costly renewable energy a more fair-dinkum strategy would be to encourage technology that captures greenhouse emissions like carbon dioxide.
27. Solar power is pointless because it can't guarantee constant supply, for obvious reasons: the sun doesn't always shine.
28. Nuclear has a few dangers, but they're trivial compared with the dangers of emitting greenhouse gases and letting global warming happen.
29. I don't want the implementation of new energy technologies to disrupt my way of life.
30. The petroleum age is far from over, we will still be able to keep finding more oil.
31. Combining technologies in the energy sector is a much more promising and more productive approach than relying on a single approach. 
32. Renewable sources do not have the potential to meet our future energy needs as they stand.
33. Many big ticket solutions to energy problems that we don't understand are just too risky.
34. Geothermal or hot rock technology will provide a reliable and unlimited and cheap energy source.
35. Energy technologies are pretty complex, so I leave it to the experts. 
36. I'm not pro-nuclear, I'm not pro-coal, I'm not pro-wind, I'm not pro any kind of generation. I'm pro-energy conservation through changes to our behavioural and design practices.
37. We need coal because it is a cheap and reliable energy source.
38. The urgency of addressing greenhouse emissions cannot stay on back burner for too much longer. So we need to find a solution quickly, such as CO2 capture and storage.
39. Australia spends too much on research and development in energy technologies.
40. Can we be confident, that if we store CO2 the storage facility is going to hold it forever? That's really the issue. And I don't think anybody can answer that question.
41. Natural gas is the bridging fuel between the oil economy and the hydrogen economy.
42. Nuclear is the inevitable replacement for old hydrocarbon technology. It is cost-competitive with coal and will cogenerate potable water and hydrogen also at societally acceptable costs.
43. Environmental, reliability and cost issues will limit the adoption of large-scale  of certain renewable technologies. 
44. Australia should  turn more attention to biomass energy sources because it is CO2 neutral (the carbon dioxide used by the growing plants is released when they are burned).
45. Our present energy system is so cheap precisely because it is unsustainable.
