prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 38 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 38 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 38 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Participants should be contacted every time researchers want to use their samples for research.
2. The community that donates samples for research should receive improved medical services.  
3. I trust researchers to control access to my personal samples.
4. Race is a useful topic for genetic studies.
5. It is always permissible to do research on my personally identifiable sample without my prior permission.  
6. Sampling some people in an ethnocultural community is acceptable only if the whole ethnocultural community has agreed to participate.
7. Biobanks need independent review boards to determine who should have access to samples. 
8. The priority for healthcare should be to reduce inequalities and the burden of disease.
9. Participants should always be able to withdraw their sample from research at anytime. 
10. My personal sample should never be anonymized since I should be informed of important research results.  
11. I should have property rights to my tissues before or after they leave my body.
12. If someone is a carrier of a genetic disease, they have a responsibility to participate in genetic research.
13. Biobanks will only lead to expensive treatments and high profits. 
14. High-priced genetic research is diverting funds that could be used to promote public health.
15. Participants who donate their samples for research should be given special access to the treatments and therapies that result from that research. 
16. Genetic research will improve our lives.
17. All participants should be paid for donating their samples to a biobank. 
18. There is no point in consulting the public about ethical issues in science and technology.
19. Genetic studies of race on enthocultural communities will lead to the discrimination of those same enthocultural communities. 
20. Permission from the indigenous community must be sought if samples are collected from indigenous peoples.
21. Genetic information is different from health information. 
22. I do not care if my donated sample is connected to my name and medical information.
23. Policy makers should consider the possibility that Canada should not pursue biobanking.
24. Scientists should have access to all unidentified, personal samples for research.
25. Aboriginal communities require special consideration concerning healthcare and research.
26. Deciding how to regulate biobanks should be left to the government. 
27. Educating people about health issues (e.g. diet and lifestyle changes) promises greater health effects than investing in biobanks.
28. Profits from biobanking should be returned to the donating community. 
29. Researchers should be allowed to use samples for research but they should not own them.  
30. The fact that we cannot predict what biobanks will be used for bothers me. 
31. Genetic studies of disability will lead to the discrimination of people living with the same conditions.
32. Participants should be active in the set up and oversight of  biobanks. 
33. The confidentiality of personal medical information is critical in any circumstance where research is being conducted.
34. There is no risk to the participants who donate to biobanks.
35. Biobanks are useful even if they only produce more scientific knowledge and not medical advancements.
36. Everyone should donate samples to a biobank for the benefit of everyone. 
37. Public funds should pay for biobanks, instead of private companies.  
38. To me, religious communities need to be consulted about genetic and biobank research.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 7 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 7 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Use of stored data and biological samples for research requires approval by an appropriate governing body (e.g., research ethics board), regardless of whether the individual is identifiable.
2. Regardless of privacy and oversight, it is most important to prevent discrimination (e.g., through insurance, social attitudes) that might result from research on collections of data and biological samples.
3. Every use of stored data and biological samples for research requires the authorization of individuals, even if the use does not identify the individual.
4. Use of stored data and biological samples for research requires approval by an appropriate governing body (e.g., research ethics board), ONLY when the individual is identifiable.
5. Use of stored data and biological samples for research requires authorization from individuals ONLY when the individual is identifiable.
6. Regardless of privacy and oversight, it is most important to ensure benefits to society or the community (e.g., geographical, ethno-cultural) participating in a collection of data and biological samples.
7. Use of stored data and biological samples for research requires authorization from individuals only when they are identifiable AND approval by an appropriate governing body (e.g. research ethics board) when they are not identifiable.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Prioritized oversight, preventing discrimination, and societal benefits over individual authorization.

## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 31 [Considerations] below from 1 to 7, where 1 is strongly disagree and 7 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 31 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 31 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. The community should be involved in discussions about climate adaptation.
2. I think it is safe to say climate change is here.
3. I don't know what to do. I'm very concerned and would like to do something, but I don't have a realistic shortlist of things that would really make a difference.
4. Increased costs for insurance are a serious concern in respect to climate change.
5. I'm not going to do anything to address climate change because it is not a major issue.
6. Climate variation is normal, so why should this be a problem?
7. I don't trust what scientists say about climate change.
8. There is no urgent need to prepare for an increase in illness and death caused by high temperatures.
9. The climate threat to the Alpine glaciers is too far away from local issues to be of concern.
10. It is NOT necessary to engage with the community when deciding what are the most important issues for planning for climate adaptation.
11. It is important to plan for migration by people displaced by climate impacts.
12. I don't trust what I hear about climate change from government.
13. It's difficult to trust what comes out in the media on the issue of climate change.
14. There's not much point in me doing anything to fix this. No-one else is going to.
15. The main focus of planning for climate adaptation should be to prepare for extreme weather events, such as drought and flooding. 
16. Occorre tenere conto degli effetti negativi del cambiamento climatico sul commercio locale.
17. We need to deal with the urban heat island effect through measures such as planting trees.
18. We need (local) funding to boost our emergency response for events such as flooding.
19. I believe that the difference we can have as an individual, in Switzerland, is so minimal that our actions are worthless.
20. Health services need to prepare for the physical impacts of climate change on health (such as heat stroke) and the impacts on mental health (such as farmers who lose their crops).
21. Councils have all the resources they need to adapt effectively to climate change.
22. Doing something to reduce emissions feels a bit hopeless but I just want to feel that I'm doing the most I can.
23. There is not enough information to definitively say that climate change is real.
24. We need to focus on adaptation actions that are concerned with the economic future of the country.
25. It is important to support vulnerable groups (elderly, children, disabled, low-income) as they have the fewest resources to deal with impacts of climate change. 
26. We should focus on protecting human systems rather than environmental ecosystems.
27. Planning for climate adaptation needs a holistic approach, considering a whole range of issues, instead of focussing on individual issues. 
28. Switzerland is particularly vulnerable to climate change, and it is in our interest to help find an effective global solution.
29. We need to make sure we have a good local response for disasters to deal with extreme weather.
30. If Switzerland reduces greenhouse gases it won't make a difference.
31. Some communities will be more affected than others by climate change, but this is not a priority issue.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 7 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 7 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Policies that involve a moderate cut in CO2 emissions (at least 25% in over the next 10 years).
2. Leave the policy settings as they are.
3. Adaptation policies and expenditure. Planning controls and emergency response programs.
4. Policies that emphasise economic growth over climate change adaptation or mitigation.
5. Policies that involve a dramatic cut back in CO2 emissions (at least 50% in the next 10 years).
6. Adaptation policies that target individual, small business or community-based actions (e.g., support the installation of alternative energy generators, insulation, water use efficiency)
7. Preparing for climate risk through the development of new approaches and technologies that enhance resilience to the impacts of climate variability or change.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Prioritize dramatic emissions cuts and resilience through new tech; deprioritize status quo policies.

1. Food that is NOT environmentally-sustainable, healthy and fairly-produced should be clearly labelled
2. Eating sustainably is too expensive, and only wealthy people can afford it
3. Restaurants in schools or retirement homes should only offer vegetarian menus.
4. Products that employ products that damage the environment, such as palm oil, should be taxed in a similar fashion to tobacco products
5. Animal antibiotical resistance will be the source of the next global pandemic
6. If Switzerland implements strong regulations on importing environmentally-sustainable and fairly-produced food, we would either have to step out of our international trade agreements or have to renegotiate most of them
7. Climate variation is normal, so why should this be a problem?
8. Climate warming will ultimately benefit food production globally as plants better growth in higher temperature
9. Farmers should be encouraged to practice ecologically sustainable agriculture, such as permaculture.
10. Intensive animal farming and monocultural plantation guarantees food supply
11. Food waste is an important social issue (e.g. hunger in the world)
12. The government should ensure that farmers are paid fair prices for their produce to secure higher incomes for those working in agriculture
13. Switzerland already has some of the toughest regulations about protecting our environment and agriculture
14. It is essential to always have fresh products available to be prepared for any situation (e.g. unexpected guests)
15. Subsidies should only be given to farmers that do not use pesticides or antibiotics
16. Biodiversity is at risk due to the use of pesticides and monoculture farming
17. The government should apply costum duties on imported products that can be produced in Switzerland (e.g., cheese, honey, apples, beef)
18. In Switzerland, packaging waste is a greater environmental issue than food thrown away
19. Banning pesticides might help the local biodiversity but decreases our food production capacity and autonomy
20. I don't care where the product I am buying comes from.
21. I am happy to change my nutrition habits, as use leftovers in future meals, if this helps to prevent food waste
22. I am happy to buy fairtrade products, like chocolate or coffee, even if they are of lower quality
23. Food waste is a major environmental issue
24. We should introduce taxes to prevent food waste
25. Strong regulation of food products will eventually damage our economic relationship with other countries
26. Extreme weather disasters affect global food availability
27. I think it is safe to say climate change is here.
28. Food thrown away is natural and biodegradable and thus not an issue for the environment
29. I am happy to pay a higher price for local or organic food products
30. To give subsidies only to farmers who do not use pesticides is an "extreme" approach that would mean falling crop yields and higher food prices

2. Political measures that include radical regulation toward sustainable food production (e.g., banning all pesticides, banning the import of foods produced using unsustainable methods).
3. Political measures that include moderate regulation toward sustainable food production (e.g., banning certain pesticides, providing incentives for organic farming).

5. Leave the policy settings as they are.

- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.

response: I prioritize incentivizing sustainable local production and moderate regulation over radical changes.

## [Example output]:

## [Considerations]:
1. It is difficult to trust what the media report about climate change.
2. Climate change is primarily caused by human activity.
3. It is certain to say that climate change exists.
4. It is important to focus on adaptation measures that take into account the country's economic future.
5. It is NOT necessary to involve society in deciding which key issues are important for climate change adaptation planning.
6. It is difficult to trust scientists' reports on climate change.
7. It is important to support vulnerable groups (the elderly, children, people with disabilities, low-income individuals) as they have fewer resources to deal with the impacts of climate change.
8. It is necessary to have strong on-the-ground disaster response capabilities to deal with extreme weather conditions.
9. Authorities should receive additional funding to strengthen measures against emergencies and weather-related disasters such as floods.
10. Health systems must prepare for both the physical health impacts of climate change (e.g., heat stroke) and the mental health impacts (e.g., farmers losing their crops).
11. There is no urgent need to prepare for an increase in illnesses and deaths caused by high temperatures.
12. I believe that the impact we can achieve as individuals in Switzerland is so small that our actions are useless.
13. Planning climate change response measures requires a global approach that considers a wide range of interventions rather than specific individual actions.
14. It doesn't make much sense for me to do anything to solve the problem. No one else is doing anything.
15. Doing something to reduce emissions seems a bit hopeless to me, but I just want to feel like I'm doing my best.
16. Some countries or regions of the world will be more affected by climate change than others, but this is not our top priority.
17. The planning of measures to tackle climate change should focus primarily on extreme weather events such as droughts and floods.
18. I don't know what to do. I am very worried and would like to do something, but I don't have a realistic set of actions that would truly make a difference.
19. There is not enough information to conclusively say that climate change is real.
20. It is important to prepare for the migration of people displaced by the effects of climate change.
21. Society should be included in the discussion on climate change adaptation.
22. I'm not going to do anything about climate change because it's not an important issue.
23. Even if Switzerland were to reduce all its CO₂ emissions, global warming would continue.
24. We should focus on protecting human systems rather than protecting ecosystems.
25. Rising insurance costs are a serious problem related to climate change.
26. We need to take into account the negative effects of climate change on local businesses.
27. Authorities have the resources they need to effectively adapt to climate change.
28. Switzerland is particularly vulnerable to climate change, and it is in our interest to contribute to an effective global solution.
29. Climate change is natural; there is no need to worry.
30. It is difficult to trust government reports on climate change.
31. The urban heat island effect must be tackled with measures such as planting trees.
32. The melting of Alpine glaciers is not a real problem for our daily lives.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 7 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 7 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Leave the policy settings as they are.
2. Policies that emphasise economic growth over climate change adaptation or mitigation.
3. "Policies that involve a moderate reduction in CO₂ emissions (e.g., reducing emissions by 25% to 50% over the next 10 years)."
4. "Policies that involve a radical reduction in CO₂ emissions (e.g., reducing emissions by 50% to 100% over the next 10 years)."
5. Adaptation policies that target individual, small business or community-based actions (e.g., support the installation of alternative energy generators, insulation, water use efficiency)
6. Adaptation policies and expenditure. Planning controls and emergency response programs.
7. Preparing for climate risk through the development of new approaches and technologies that enhance resilience to the impacts of climate variability or change.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Prioritize radical emissions reduction, resilience technologies, and adaptation planning over inaction.

## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 36 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- Using the Q Methodology, rate the statements following a Fixed Quasi-Normal Distribution between 1 and 11.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 36 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 36 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. We should definitely preserve the heritage value of the bridge, but only if it is financially viable.
2. When deciding about the future of the bridge, indigenous concerns should be given adequate consideration. 
3. The safety of the bridge is more important than its appearance.
4. As long as there is a bridge that I can cross, I don't care about its structure.
5. The bridge is certainly an attractive entry statement to Fremantle and without doubt far more important than trucks.
6. The old bridge provides a scenic entrance to Fremantle that attracts tourists.
7. Alterations will lead to nothing but the uglification of the bridge.
8. Since the traffic bridge has important heritage significance, the only grounds for its removal should be on the grounds of serious safety issues and verified by heritage engineers.
9. Providing a better pedestrian and cycle traffic should be the main consideration when deciding about the future of the bridge.
10. The Fremantle Traffic Bridge is the most iconic landmark and the main tourist attraction in Fremantle. 
11. This magnificent timber bridge is a rare and beautiful sight in today's world, it should be preserved. 
12. Altering or replacing the existing Fremantle Bridge means diminishing Fremantle.
13. Safe and efficient movement of all road and river users across and under the bridge should the main considerations
14. There are no specific economic benefits for the Fremantle from the bridge.
15. Reducing the risk of vessel collision on the Swan River should be the main consideration when deciding about the future of the bridge
16. Indigenous people would want to minimize impact on the Swan River, a registered site, that is of importance and significance to them.
17. The existing bridge is too low; archways too narrow and do not line up with the railway bridge making navigation dangerous. 
18. The critical infrastructure of the bridge raises serious safety concerns. 
19. River craft deserve better traffic conditions on the Swan River.
20. Replacing timber elements with steel components would destroy the authentic appearance of the bridge.
21. The problem is not the vulnerable structure of the bridge but excessive traffic, which should be reduced.
22. Any changes to the bridge should give right consideration to the environment.bridge
23. We just got traffic calming in Town Centre after 25 years effort. I don't want bridge to be build bigger, better faster to reverse the gains of the last 25 years.
24. It is worth spending money to retain the iconic status of the bridge.
25. The bridge has stood the test of time for the past 67 years; there's no need for major changes to it.
26. The cost of maintaining the old timber structure is too high.
27. We shouldn't stick to the past when deciding about the future of the bridge, we should be open for modern design options.
28. The Fremantle Bridge is irreplaceable. It is a strong, enduring part of our history.
29. The function of the Fremantle Bridge as a transport gateway is more important than its heritage.
30. The most important thing is that access to Fremantle from its north is maintained in the most undisturbed manner as possible. 
31. The old bridge will never be able to handle vehicles, bike and pedestrians at the same time.
32. Whatever works are undertaken, the heritage value of the old bridge will be affected.
33. The most important issue for cyclists is safety, which means they need access across the bridge which has a good surface.
34. Tax payers money should be spent on services that are more essential than upgrading the bridge.
35. It is most important that the solution is a long term one.
36. The main concern is to have a bridge that underpins the economic activities in the region.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 6 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 6, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 6 the option you support the least.

2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

1. Construct a new standard bridge next to the current bridge, leaving a section of the existing bridge as a heritage and recreation site
2. Construct a new bridge that is a major entry statements for Fremantle, leaving a section of the existing bridge as a heritage recreation site
3. Retain existing bridge, but replace the navigation spans and deteriorated components
4. Construct a new standard bridge and retain the existing bridge as a pedestrian/cyclist facility
5. Construct a new two lane standard bridge and retain the existing bridge as a 2 lane bridge with improved pedestrian/cyclist facilities
6. Retain existing bridge, but replace the navigation spans and deteriorated components and incorporate bridge widening

## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 20 [Considerations] below from 1 to 7, where 1 is strongly disagree and 7 is strongly agree.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Schools should play a crucial role in creating a supportive environment, both online and offline, to mitigate the negative impact of social media on mental health.
2. People should take responsibility for actively addressing their own biases and prejudices against individuals with mental health disorders.
3. Mental health problems are solely medical in nature and not a social issue.
4. People with mental disorders should not be allowed to work with children.
5. Social media contribute to mental health issues through cyberbullying, social comparison, and unrealistic portrayals of life.
6. Focusing on prevention strategies (e.g., government media campaigns) is essential to reducing the impact of stigma associated with mental health conditions.
7. Social media platforms should be required to have parental controls.
8. Improving working or study conditions does not impact people's mental health in any way.
9. Personal solutions (such as joining a yoga club) are more effective than government intervention in addressing mental health issues (such as having social workers or psychologists in schools).
10. Minors under the age of 16 should be legally prohibited from using social media.
11. Mental health can be understood in different ways. A comprehensive definition of mental health should take into account social issues such as poverty, inequality, and discrimination.
12. Mental health issues require less urgency and fewer resources compared to physical health conditions.
13. To prevent people with mental health issues from feeling lonely or isolated, we should talk more about these topics in schools and workplaces to increase public understanding and sensitivity.
14. Individuals should take responsibility for their own mental well-being.
15. Personal cultural or religious beliefs and preferences should guide the choice of treatment methods, including therapy and medication.
16. Investing in mental health services in schools and workplaces (for example, having social workers in facilities) is essential to prevent negative mental health outcomes.
17. Private mental health services are better than public ones, so Switzerland's mental health system should be entirely privatized.
18. It is good that basic health insurance does not fully cover mental health care since only a few people need it.
19. More government funding is needed to improve mental health services and their accessibility, especially for marginalized people subject to socioeconomic disparities.
20. Being poor, living far from urban centers, or being a victim of racism are examples of factors that can influence a person's willingness to seek help for mental health problems.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 43 [Considerations] below from 1 to 7, where 1 is strongly disagree and 7 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 43 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 43 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. The Swiss food system depends on imports from other countries, and it is in our interest to help find an effective global solution.
2. I think it is safe to say climate change is here.
3. Sustainable agriculture increases prices and harms consumer freedom. The production should be adapted to what people demand.
4. Some communities are more affected than others by the global agri-food system, but this is not a priority issue.
5. I'm not going to do anything to address the impacts of the agri-food system because it is not a major issue.
6. It is NOT necessary to engage with the community when deciding what are the most important issues for planning for food system changes.
7. There is no urgent need to prepare for an increase in illness and death caused by intensive use of pesticides/antibiotics
8. I don't trust what I hear about climate change from government.
9. Climate variation is normal, so why should this be a problem?
10. Products that use environmentally harmful ingredients, such as palm oil, should be taxed in the same way as tobacco products.
11. It is important to support smal land local farming as they have the fewest resources to deal with impacts of climate change. 
12. We need actions to protect inhabitants and the biodiversity from harmful pesticide.
13. There is not enough information to definitively say that climate change is real.
14. As long as we use animals in agriculture, it cannot be sustainable
15. Agriculture is already very sustainable. Swiss farmers are on the right track
16. “Farmers already suffer enough from strict rules and paperwork. Family farmers should have more liberties”
17. The Swiss food system is particularly vulnerable to climate change, and it is in our interest to help find an effective global solution.
18. “Actions on the food system in Switzerland will lead to increased imports and shift of the pollution abroad”
19. “Food accessibility (price) and security (availability) is NOT COMPATIBLE with a sustainable food system”
20. It is important to plan for migration by people displaced by malnutrition and famine.
21. We should focus on protecting human systems rather than environmental ecosystems.
22. I don't know what to do. I'm very concerned and would like to do something, but I don't have a realistic shortlist of things that would really make a difference.
23. The main focus of planning for adaptation should be to prepare the food system for extreme weather events, such as drought and flooding. 
24. I don't trust what scientists say about climate change.
25. Climate warming will ultimately benefit food production globally as plants better growth in higher temperature
26. We need to focus on adaptation actions that are concerned with the economic future of the country.
27. The negative effects of the climate change on local commerce should be taken into account.
28. There's not much point in me doing anything to make agriculture more sustainable. No-one else is going to.
29. Banning pesticides might help the local biodiversity but decreases our food production capacity and autonomy
30. There is not enough information to definitively establish if the link between the agri-food system and climate change is real.
31. We need to deal with the water pollution issue through measures such as reducing fertilizer and pesticide use.
32. If Switzerland reduces greenhouse gases of its food system it won't make a difference.
33. Planning for food system adaptation needs a holistic approach, considering a whole range of issues, instead of focussing on individual issues. 
34. “Intensive food production can go along with the protection of the environment and health”
35. I am happy to pay a higher price for local or organic food products
36. The community should be involved in discussions about food system adaptation.
37. Climate change will not be a problem because there will be technological solutions available.
38. Eating sustainably is too expensive, and only wealthy people can afford it
39. We should develop short distribution channels and support local production instead of supporting big agrifood corporations
40. Strong regulation of food production will eventually damage our economic relationship with other countries
41. Agricultural subsidies should promote sustainable, pesticide and antibiotic-free production.
42. It's difficult to trust what comes out in the media on the issue of climate change.
43. I believe that the difference we can have as an individual, in Switzerland, is so minimal that our actions are worthless.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 7 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 7 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Policies that involve a moderate sustainable regulations (e.g., banning certain types of pesticides, incentivising organic agriculture)
2. Policies that emphasise fewer regulations (e.g., policies that promote free trade agreements by reducing food regulation)
3. Leave the policy settings as they are.
4. Policies that create incentives for local producers to produce sustainable food (e.g., subsidies or tax breaks for local farmers who produce organic products)
5. Adaptation policies and expenditure. Planning controls and emergency response programs.
6. Preparing for climate risk for food production through the development of new approaches and technologies that enhance resilience to the impacts of climate variability or change.
7. Policies that involve a radical sustainable food regulation (e.g., banning all pesticides, banning the importation of food related product that employ non-sustanable approaches, exclusively incentivising organic agriculture)

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: I prioritize policies that incentivize sustainable local food production and prepare for climate risks.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 45 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 45 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 45 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Can we be confident, that if we store CO2 the storage facility is going to hold it forever? That's really the issue. And I don't think anybody can answer that question.
2. Local energy solutions such as windfarms are good for jobs, local economies and tourism.
3. Nuclear has a few dangers, but they're trivial compared with the dangers of emitting greenhouse gases and letting global warming happen.
4. Using biomass from crops has significant expansion potential and would be good for the rural industry.
5. Renewables are part of the long-term solution, but for the foreseeable future, they just can't do the job.
6. The limited strategic and technical insight that is so entrenched in Australia is limiting the development of innovative energy technologies.
7. Australia should  turn more attention to biomass energy sources because it is CO2 neutral (the carbon dioxide used by the growing plants is released when they are burned).
8. It is very hard to trust all these so-called experts arguing for one energy technology or another, especially when they, or their bosses, are just in it to make money.
9. Energy is going to get costly so we had better start investing in alternatives.
10. Australia spends too much on research and development in energy technologies.
11. Our present energy system is so cheap precisely because it is unsustainable.
12. Wind power has its downsides — it is highly visible and can kill birds. The fact is though, that any man-made structure can kill birds.	
13. Nuclear is the inevitable replacement for old hydrocarbon technology. It is cost-competitive with coal and will cogenerate potable water and hydrogen also at societally acceptable costs.
14. Renewable sources do not have the potential to meet our future energy needs as they stand.
15. Energy technologies are pretty complex, so I leave it to the experts. 
16. Any tax to reduce greenhouse gas emissions will have a detrimental economic effect on the nation.
17. You could have a wind farm across all of the outback that would kill every kookaburra, but it wouldn't provide the baseload power we need.
18. Natural gas is the bridging fuel between the oil economy and the hydrogen economy.
19. Coal-powered energy needs to be minimised because of its high greenhouse gas emissions.
20. Nuclear power is a more proven technology than it was 30 years ago. In reality atomic power generation can be a very safe system if designed and operated correctly.
21. Many big ticket solutions to energy problems that we don't understand are just too risky.
22. Energy technologies such as nuclear power and geosequestration are too risky. It's better to improve the technologies that we already have.
23. Climate change considerations have no role in the development of national and global energy policies.
24. Combining technologies in the energy sector is a much more promising and more productive approach than relying on a single approach. 
25. Geothermal or hot rock technology will provide a reliable and unlimited and cheap energy source.
26.  If Australia mines uranium, the country should be able to generate power from it.
27. Prices of alternative energy will fall as technology improves.
28. Fuzzy-headed thinking about alternative energy sources seems not to appreciate the need for certainty of supply and excess capacity to keep economies growing.
29. There is no need make expensive investments in technological changes within the energy sector.
30. I'm not pro-nuclear, I'm not pro-coal, I'm not pro-wind, I'm not pro any kind of generation. I'm pro-energy conservation through changes to our behavioural and design practices.
31. If the cost of greenhouse gas emissions is factored in, the cost of renewables compared to coal isn't so big.
32. Rather than look at costly renewable energy a more fair-dinkum strategy would be to encourage technology that captures greenhouse emissions like carbon dioxide.
33. Reducing greenhouse gases should not mean prices have to go up.
34. Reducing our reliance on oil would be good for the economy and the environment.
35. Apart from coal, natural gas is the only other potentially reliable source of power for the state.
36. I don't want the implementation of new energy technologies to disrupt my way of life.
37. Environmental, reliability and cost issues will limit the adoption of large-scale  of certain renewable technologies. 
38. Governments must fund new infrastructure investment in the face of uncertainty in the economics of energy technologies.
39. The urgency of addressing greenhouse emissions cannot stay on back burner for too much longer. So we need to find a solution quickly, such as CO2 capture and storage.
40. Coal gasification is needed to produce hydrogen on the scale required for a possible transition to a hydrogen-based economy.
41. Any return on geosequestration is 15 to 20 years off, whereas the proven technology of renewable energy offers immediate gains.
42. Solar power is pointless because it can't guarantee constant supply, for obvious reasons: the sun doesn't always shine.
43. Australia doesn't support alternative energy opportunities. Industry comes along and says, 'Have I got something for you' (such as carbon sequestration, or a new power station) and they get government subsidies to do it.
44. The petroleum age is far from over, we will still be able to keep finding more oil.
45. We need coal because it is a cheap and reliable energy source.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 9 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 9, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 9 the option you support the least.

## [Example output]:

2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Coal with CO2 Burial
2. Biomass
3. Wind
4. Hydroelectric
5. Coal
6. Solar Energy
7. Natural Gas
8. Nuclear Energy
9. Geothermal Energy

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Geothermal and wind are promising clean energy sources, while coal has high greenhouse gas emissions.

20. The petroleum age is far from over, we will still be able to keep finding more oil.
21. Energy technologies are pretty complex, so I leave it to the experts.

23. Renewables are part of the long-term solution, but for the foreseeable future, they just can't do the job.
24. Coal-powered energy needs to be minimised because of its high greenhouse gas emissions.
25. I'm not pro-nuclear, I'm not pro-coal, I'm not pro-wind, I'm not pro any kind of generation. I'm pro-energy conservation through changes to our behavioural and design practices.
26. Energy is going to get costly so we had better start investing in alternatives.
27. Nuclear has a few dangers, but they're trivial compared with the dangers of emitting greenhouse gases and letting global warming happen.
28.  If Australia mines uranium, the country should be able to generate power from it.
29. We need coal because it is a cheap and reliable energy source.
30. Energy technologies such as nuclear power and geosequestration are too risky. It's better to improve the technologies that we already have.
31. Wind power has its downsides — it is highly visible and can kill birds. The fact is though, that any man-made structure can kill birds.	
32. Apart from coal, natural gas is the only other potentially reliable source of power for the state.
33. Rather than look at costly renewable energy a more fair-dinkum strategy would be to encourage technology that captures greenhouse emissions like carbon dioxide.
34. I don't want the implementation of new energy technologies to disrupt my way of life.
35. Australia doesn't support alternative energy opportunities. Industry comes along and says, 'Have I got something for you' (such as carbon sequestration, or a new power station) and they get government subsidies to do it.
36. The urgency of addressing greenhouse emissions cannot stay on back burner for too much longer. So we need to find a solution quickly, such as CO2 capture and storage.
37. Any tax to reduce greenhouse gas emissions will have a detrimental economic effect on the nation.
38. Many big ticket solutions to energy problems that we don't understand are just too risky.
39. Prices of alternative energy will fall as technology improves.
40. Nuclear is the inevitable replacement for old hydrocarbon technology. It is cost-competitive with coal and will cogenerate potable water and hydrogen also at societally acceptable costs.
41. Australia spends too much on research and development in energy technologies.
42. Our present energy system is so cheap precisely because it is unsustainable.
43. It is very hard to trust all these so-called experts arguing for one energy technology or another, especially when they, or their bosses, are just in it to make money.
44. Solar power is pointless because it can't guarantee constant supply, for obvious reasons: the sun doesn't always shine.
45. Natural gas is the bridging fuel between the oil economy and the hydrogen economy.

24. Any tax to reduce greenhouse gas emissions will have a detrimental economic effect on the nation.
25. Governments must fund new infrastructure investment in the face of uncertainty in the economics of energy technologies.
26. Can we be confident, that if we store CO2 the storage facility is going to hold it forever? That's really the issue. And I don't think anybody can answer that question.
27. I'm not pro-nuclear, I'm not pro-coal, I'm not pro-wind, I'm not pro any kind of generation. I'm pro-energy conservation through changes to our behavioural and design practices.
28. Many big ticket solutions to energy problems that we don't understand are just too risky.
29. There is no need make expensive investments in technological changes within the energy sector.
30. Energy technologies such as nuclear power and geosequestration are too risky. It's better to improve the technologies that we already have.
31. Our present energy system is so cheap precisely because it is unsustainable.
32. Fuzzy-headed thinking about alternative energy sources seems not to appreciate the need for certainty of supply and excess capacity to keep economies growing.
33. Nuclear has a few dangers, but they're trivial compared with the dangers of emitting greenhouse gases and letting global warming happen.
34. Renewable sources do not have the potential to meet our future energy needs as they stand.
35. Prices of alternative energy will fall as technology improves.
36. Solar power is pointless because it can't guarantee constant supply, for obvious reasons: the sun doesn't always shine.
37. Reducing greenhouse gases should not mean prices have to go up.
38. Energy technologies are pretty complex, so I leave it to the experts. 
39. The limited strategic and technical insight that is so entrenched in Australia is limiting the development of innovative energy technologies.
40. The petroleum age is far from over, we will still be able to keep finding more oil.
41. Australia doesn't support alternative energy opportunities. Industry comes along and says, 'Have I got something for you' (such as carbon sequestration, or a new power station) and they get government subsidies to do it.
42. I don't want the implementation of new energy technologies to disrupt my way of life.
43. Local energy solutions such as windfarms are good for jobs, local economies and tourism.
44. Apart from coal, natural gas is the only other potentially reliable source of power for the state.
45. We need coal because it is a cheap and reliable energy source.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 36 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- Using the Q Methodology, rate the statements following a Fixed Quasi-Normal Distribution between 1 and 11.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 36 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 36 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. through the fusion we will be able to derogare il patto di stabilita' and therefore unblock some founds. The latter can be invested in the municipalities that are more in need 
2. with or without the amalgamation, the important thing that is at the practical level, nothing will change. For example the offices should stay where they are.
3. the fusion is necessary to lower the taxes
4. the fusion benefits the bigger mnicipalities at the detriment of the smalles also with respect to the external fundings.
5. the fusion is an innovative process that will make as an example to follow for italy and the rest of europe.
6. in this fusion there is no project, no vision and nos trategy. Things should be done in a very different way.
7. the new municipality will be politically more powerful in front of other municipalities like Bologna metropolitan. In this way our interests will be protected outside our municiplity.
8. it is not necessary to be big to be good. The small municipalities can be better managed of the bigger and do more things. It is a matter of good administration.
9. the fusion is a leap in the unknown
10. the fusion will bring the resources to make the intervention that our territory needs, like the bycicle paths or the public transport between the municipalities or the high school.
11. the needs of the citizens are too different acros the municipalities. It will be too difficult for The amalgameted municipality to answer to everybody.
12. the fusion is a decision that has already been taken and they are trying to imposing it top down. They are trying to sell the product "amalgamated municipality"
13. it is not yet clear how are they are going to amalgamate the contracts of the municipal clerks across the territory. things like these should be decided before the amalgamtion.
14. the union is a failure and a cost, because it absorbed just a very small part of the services and the money
15. in this days of crisis and changes at the european level, the amalgamation is necessary and opportune.
16. the consequence of the fusion is that either we will pay more than before or they will cut the services
17. we are misusing the fusion. The needs of the territory are not being respected and the valsmaoggia is being used as a labrat
18. there are not enoughf elements do decide in favor or against the fusion
19. the fusion is too risky because is a oneway process
20. the fusion is not the only solution to the issues of our territory but it is the more concrete
21. through the fusion we will be able to exploit the potentials of the territory to improve the building-, commercial- handcraft- and agricoltural development.
22. the fusion seem to me another way to change everything to change nothing
23. the amalgamation will erease the local diversities
24. the fusion will change our relationship with the administration. The fusionwill move away the administration and the power from the local territory and centralizing it somwhere else
25. if the administration chose for the fusion it means that it is the right choice. This choice should be taken by the experts not the citizens
26. the fusion is a samll step to complete a path of amalgamation that started 20 years ago. The amalgamated municipality it is a realty in facts. How much do we have to wait still?
27. it is not possible to say yes or not to the amalgamation without knowing how it will be, how much will it cost and how it will be done.
28. the fusion is the right answer to the limit of the union
29. if the fusion will not be done, the single municipalities will not be capable of maintaining the current quality of the services.
30. I would not like that the money of my taxes would be used in the municiplities next to mine
31. the shift from the union to the fusion is a step to big which brings too many uncertainties. If things are done more gradually the change will be hurtless because people will be already used to it.
32. the choice of the fusion is due to the wish of certain political parties to maintain the political dominance
33. it is not worth to make the amalgamation in this time of reorganization with the metropolitan bologna
34. the amalgamation will benefit the emplyees and the citizens. The emplyees will increase their competences through more trainings. Therefore the citizens will benefit of more specialized professionals.
35. the amalgsmation will offer the possibility of save money by cutting the political costs and the burocracy costs and making the administration more efficient.
36. with the amalgamation there will be a deficit of democracy because the municipalities will be only consultive. The citizens will have no power

3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. the fusion is an innovative process that will make as an example to follow for italy and the rest of europe.
2. with or without the amalgamation, the important thing that is at the practical level, nothing will change. For example the offices should stay where they are.
3. the fusion is a leap in the unknown
4. the fusion is a decision that has already been taken and they are trying to imposing it top down. They are trying to sell the product "amalgamated municipality"
5. the fusion is not the only solution to the issues of our territory but it is the more concrete
6. the new municipality will be politically more powerful in front of other municipalities like Bologna metropolitan. In this way our interests will be protected outside our municiplity.
7. the amalgamation will benefit the emplyees and the citizens. The emplyees will increase their competences through more trainings. Therefore the citizens will benefit of more specialized professionals.
8. through the fusion we will be able to derogare il patto di stabilita' and therefore unblock some founds. The latter can be invested in the municipalities that are more in need 
9. the union is a failure and a cost, because it absorbed just a very small part of the services and the money
10. the amalgamation will erease the local diversities
11. in this days of crisis and changes at the european level, the amalgamation is necessary and opportune.
12. the amalgsmation will offer the possibility of save money by cutting the political costs and the burocracy costs and making the administration more efficient.
13. it is not yet clear how are they are going to amalgamate the contracts of the municipal clerks across the territory. things like these should be decided before the amalgamtion.
14. the choice of the fusion is due to the wish of certain political parties to maintain the political dominance
15. it is not possible to say yes or not to the amalgamation without knowing how it will be, how much will it cost and how it will be done.
16. the shift from the union to the fusion is a step to big which brings too many uncertainties. If things are done more gradually the change will be hurtless because people will be already used to it.
17. the fusion is necessary to lower the taxes
18. the fusion will change our relationship with the administration. The fusionwill move away the administration and the power from the local territory and centralizing it somwhere else
19. the fusion is a samll step to complete a path of amalgamation that started 20 years ago. The amalgamated municipality it is a realty in facts. How much do we have to wait still?
20. the consequence of the fusion is that either we will pay more than before or they will cut the services
21. in this fusion there is no project, no vision and nos trategy. Things should be done in a very different way.
22. with the amalgamation there will be a deficit of democracy because the municipalities will be only consultive. The citizens will have no power
23. the fusion seem to me another way to change everything to change nothing
24. the fusion benefits the bigger mnicipalities at the detriment of the smalles also with respect to the external fundings.
25. through the fusion we will be able to exploit the potentials of the territory to improve the building-, commercial- handcraft- and agricoltural development.
26. it is not necessary to be big to be good. The small municipalities can be better managed of the bigger and do more things. It is a matter of good administration.
27. if the fusion will not be done, the single municipalities will not be capable of maintaining the current quality of the services.
28. the fusion is the right answer to the limit of the union
29. we are misusing the fusion. The needs of the territory are not being respected and the valsmaoggia is being used as a labrat
30. the needs of the citizens are too different acros the municipalities. It will be too difficult for The amalgameted municipality to answer to everybody.
31. if the administration chose for the fusion it means that it is the right choice. This choice should be taken by the experts not the citizens
32. it is not worth to make the amalgamation in this time of reorganization with the metropolitan bologna
33. the fusion is too risky because is a oneway process
34. the fusion will bring the resources to make the intervention that our territory needs, like the bycicle paths or the public transport between the municipalities or the high school.
35. there are not enoughf elements do decide in favor or against the fusion
36. I would not like that the money of my taxes would be used in the municiplities next to mine

## [Considerations]:
1. Climate change is an immediate threat requiring action.
2. If we are serious about maintaining and improving people's living standards in Townsville, we need to make the most out of coal exports.
3. While job creation is important, we should prioritise industries that have less impact on the reef over those that have greater impact on the reef. 
4. We should prioritise economic development and job creation in Townsville over the environment. 
5. Coal-generated electricity must be phased out if we are to avoid catastrophic impacts of global warming, including the loss of the Great Barrier Reef.
6. Deep-pocketed green groups are willing to sacrifice our local economy for their own goals. 
7. There are more jobs to lose from Great Barrier Reef tourism than to be gained from the coal industry.
8. There is no point throwing money at protecting the reef if our other actions contribute to its continuing decline.
9. I think enough is being done to effectively manage the Great Barrier Reef.
10. More scientific research is needed before we can say if climate change is a threat to the Great Barrier Reef.
11. Mining development in Australia is a risk to the environment.
12. A few self-interested politicians and influential companies are prepared to sacrifice our well-being for their own short-term gain.
13. Short term development thinking will ultimately lead to longer term reef damage and economic impacts.
14. Protection of the Great Barrier Reef is worthwhile at whatever cost.
15. If we don't take steps to protect the Great Barrier Reef future generations will miss out on the opportunity to experience the reef.
16. The mining industry provides thousands of jobs. Without it unemployment would have skyrocketed in regional Queensland.
17. The negative publicity about climate change impacts on the reef has negatively affected the local tourism industry.
18. Townsville is better off because of mining development.
19. The Great Barrier Reef underpins more direct and indirect jobs than mining does. 
20. We don't need to worry too much about environmental damage in the Great Barrier Reef because future generations will be better able to deal with these problems than we are.
21. I feel that future generations have been adequately considered in the management of the Great Barrier Reef.
22. Each new Australian coal mine will contribute greenhouse emissions that exacerbate the risk of climate change, and impacts to the Reef.
23. Government should be doing more to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
24. Australia's contribution to global greenhouse gas emissions is so small that we should wait for other countries to take action on climate change before we do. 
25. If future generations could have their say about the Great Barrier Reef, they would be less concerned about the environmental impacts than many people make out.
26. Climate change is a threat, but the impacts are too distant for immediate concern.
27. Economic development associated with mining will provide more opportunities for future generations in North Queensland.
28. The Great Barrier Reef is a great asset for the economy of this region and we should prioritise protecting it.
29. We should prioritise protecting the environment in Townsville, even if it hurts our economy.
30. Climate change impacts on the Great Barrier Reef aren't something I'm worried about.
31. Government should provide funding support for industry, including mining projects such as the Adani mine.
32. It is not possible to conserve the reef over the long term without addressing climate change 
33. There is no strong scientific evidence to suggest that the Great Barrier Reef is under threat from climate change.
34. Jobs and growth in Townsville should be prioritised over Great Barrier Reef protection.
35. The first priority should be reducing other pressures on the reef (such as agricultural runoff or coastal development) so that the reef will be more resilient to climate change impacts.

- Rate each of the 45 [Considerations] below from 1 to 7, where 1 is strongly disagree and 7 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 45 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 45 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Suggesting genome editing will 'cure' disability diminishes those living with genetic conditions who need support.
2. If we open the box of genome editing we will not know where to draw the line.
3. I worry that something will go wrong with genome technology.
4. It's better to use genome editing to prevent a serious disease from happening rather than having to treat it with conventional medicine after it has occurred.
5. Decisions about the use of genome editing are best left to the experts.
6. The use of gene editing for non-medical reasons reminds me of the Nazis during the Second World War.
7. If human genome editing can be used to make changes to humans on demand for any reason, the future will be like a dystopian movie.
8. I think it's okay to use genome editing to change someone's appearance.
9. Genome editing in agriculture will have the biggest impact on people's health. 
10. I would consider using genome editing for my children to give them an advantage in life, so long as it's safe.
11. As a society, we have an obligation to help strengthen coming generations by eradicating diseases.
12. Mitochondrial donation is a treatment more like an organ transplant, which doesn't really change the genetics of person.
13. My cultural beliefs make me cautious about genome editing.
14. I think we should keep an open mind about new discoveries.
15. I'm concerned that genome editing will lead to a reduction in genetic diversity.
16. Science and technology have too much control over our lives.
17. Parents want 'designer babies' with certain traits out of vanity.
18. If genome editing is proven to be safe, then I see no reason to oppose it.
19. It is better to accept our genes the way they are than to tamper with things we don't understand.
20. I have a more positive feeling about gene editing in humans than I do for animals or plants.
21. Genome editing is really cool science.
22. There is nothing wrong with using genome editing to speed up evolution and help living things (including humans) adapt to challenges.
23. The idea that people with genetic conditions might get cured in my lifetime is miraculous and incredible.
24. Each individual has a right to decide for themselves whether to undergo gene editing, as long as the changes cannot be passed on to future generations.
25. My concern is that as we start to tinker with the human genome, we're going to accidentally introduce a whole host of other problems.
26. I'm worried that human genome editing will widen the gap between those who can afford it and those who can't.
27. Beacause of our changing environments, I believe that future humans will need genome editing to survive.
28. Genome editing technologies gives us power over human life itself.
29. I am concerned that the use of human genome editing will advantage one group over another.
30. I think it would be amazing to have a choice in the way someone behaves.
31. Anything that's been artificially created in a lab gives me Frankenstein vibes.
32. I would be OK with having my own genome edited.
33. Genome editing will be used for enhancement by wealthy people.
34. Interfering in people's genes is intervening a bit too far in human creation.
35. Parents and guardians have a right to edit the genes of their children before they are born.
36. Editing genes that will be inherited is problematic because it means making decisions for future people who don't exist yet. 
37. It's a slippery slope from genome editing for medical reasons to using it for other reasons.
38. I believe we should remain as natural as possible but we should not shy away from furthering medicine and the chance to save lives.
39. If human genome editing is available then it should be available to everyone who needs it, not just those who can afford it.
40. The idea that genome editing can make perfect people and societies is extremely dangerous.
41. The idea of editing the human genome is scary.
42. I don't think we know enough about genetic diseases or the long term consequences of genome editing
43. When you change someone's genes you are fundamentally changing who they are.
44. I'm concerned that genome editing will be used as a quick techno-fix without actually dealing with real problems.
45. We find strength when we face illness and adversity. It makes us who we are.

1. Permit only non-heritable human genome editing in both research and in clinics and mitochondrial donation only if not for profit.
2. Permit all uses of human genome editing and mitochondrial donation only if not for profit
3. Permit non-heritable and heritable human genome editing (including mitochondrial donation), but only for clinical purposes, and if there is strong oversight, regular community input and (re)approval.
4. Prohibit all forms of human genome editing for now, except for research purposes.
5.  Permit both heritable and non-heritable uses of genome editing for any purpose with minimal restrictions to ensure safety and compliance with ethical standards.
6. Permit only non-heritable human genome editing for clinical treatments, and mitochondrial donation.

8.  Permit only non-heritable human genome editing in both research and in clinics.

1. If genome editing is proven to be safe, then I see no reason to oppose it.

12. Beacause of our changing environments, I believe that future humans will need genome editing to survive.
13. I don't think we know enough about genetic diseases or the long term consequences of genome editing
14. The idea that genome editing can make perfect people and societies is extremely dangerous.

16. Decisions about the use of genome editing are best left to the experts.
17. Editing genes that will be inherited is problematic because it means making decisions for future people who don't exist yet. 
18. I think we should keep an open mind about new discoveries.
19. I think it would be amazing to have a choice in the way someone behaves.
20. I think it's okay to use genome editing to change someone's appearance.
21. As a society, we have an obligation to help strengthen coming generations by eradicating diseases.
22. I worry that something will go wrong with genome technology.
23. Genome editing technologies gives us power over human life itself.
24. Genome editing in agriculture will have the biggest impact on people's health. 
25. It's better to use genome editing to prevent a serious disease from happening rather than having to treat it with conventional medicine after it has occurred.
26. Genome editing is really cool science.
27. It is better to accept our genes the way they are than to tamper with things we don't understand.
28. I have a more positive feeling about gene editing in humans than I do for animals or plants.
29. I'm concerned that genome editing will be used as a quick techno-fix without actually dealing with real problems.
30. The idea of editing the human genome is scary.
31. We find strength when we face illness and adversity. It makes us who we are. 
32. Each individual has a right to decide for themselves whether to undergo gene editing, as long as the changes cannot be passed on to future generations.
33. I am concerned that the use of human genome editing will advantage one group over another.
34. Science and technology have too much control over our lives.
35. The use of gene editing for non-medical reasons reminds me of the Nazis during the Second World War.
36. The idea that people with genetic conditions might get cured in my lifetime is miraculous and incredible.
37. Parents and guardians have a right to edit the genes of their children before they are born.
38. I would be OK with having my own genome edited.
39. If human genome editing can be used to make changes to humans on demand for any reason, the future will be like a dystopian movie.
40. Anything that's been artificially created in a lab gives me Frankenstein vibes.
41. My concern is that as we start to tinker with the human genome, we're going to accidentally introduce a whole host of other problems.
42. If human genome editing is available then it should be available to everyone who needs it, not just those who can afford it.
43. My cultural beliefs make me cautious about genome editing.
44. Mitochondrial donation is a treatment more like an organ transplant, which doesn't really change the genetics of person.
45. I believe we should remain as natural as possible but we should not shy away from furthering medicine and the chance to save lives.

12. Abolishing mandatory health insurance would reduce the financial burden on households.
13. Higher tax deductions for medical expenses would help households manage healthcare costs more effectively.
14. Reducing bureaucratic inefficiencies and simplifying administrative processes in healthcare could lead to significant cost savings.
15. It is important to involve more private actors in healthcare (e.g., outsourcing administrative tasks in hospitals to specialized companies) to reduce costs.
16. Higher out-of-pocket payments would prevent excessive use of healthcare services.
17. The Swiss healthcare system focuses too much on treating diseases rather than on disease prevention to improve public health.
18. Health insurance costs should be income-based to make them more affordable for lower-income individuals.
19. A more transparent healthcare system would help people understand costs and make better decisions.
20. More competition among insurance providers would lead to lower prices and better services.
21. Hospitals are more interested in maximizing their profits than in ensuring quality and access to healthcare.
22. The current system encourages excessive use of services once the deductible ('franchise') has been paid, leading to unnecessary treatments and higher overall costs.
23. More competition in mandatory health insurance, where insurers can offer alternative models, would promote innovation and efficiency in healthcare.
24. A lack of financial support for preventive measures leads to higher healthcare costs in the long run.

## [Considerations]:
1. It's OK if data that identifies me is stored in a separate database and replaced in the biobank by a unique non-identifying code.
2. People who provide samples for research should get special access to the treatments that result from this research.
3. People should be paid for providing their samples to a biobank.
4. Religious groups need to be asked for their views about biobanks and genetic research.
5. I do not mind if my sample is connected to my name and medical information.
6. Information about people's genes and the traits they inherit from their parents is more private than their medical records.
7. There is no risk to the people who provide samples and information to biobanks.
8. The biobank owner should be able to sell any information they have about my genes, if they want to.
9. My sample should never be permanently anonymized since I should be contacted about important research results
10. It is acceptable for samples and information that doesn't identify me to be sent to researchers overseas.
11. Biobanks need to be monitored and reviewed by external, independent people to prevent the misuse of data and samples.

1. Privately Funded with minimal regulation: Minimal regulation of privately run biobanking system with maximum participation of the public. Low privacy provisions.
2. Minimal Government Input: Minimal input of public resources to development biobanking Use resources  — use instead for other approaches to improving health. Fairly relaxed oversight of use of biobanks and  privacy provisions (low level of regulation).
3. High Privacy: Implementation of a (publicy or privately owned) biobanking system where privacy of individuals is paramount. Stored data and biological samples for research requires the authorization of individual donors.
4. Publicly Funded with minimal regulation: A biobanking system owned and run by the government, who is also responsible for oversight and privacy provisions, as well as controlling access.
5. Privately Funded with strong regulation: A BB system where funding is provided mostly by private companies, withstrong government oversight and privacy provisions.
6. Publicly Funded with strong regulation: A biobanking system owned and run by the government, who is also responsible for oversight and privacy provisions, as well as controlling access.
7. Cautious Implementation: Minimal input of public resources to development biobanking Use resources  — use instead for other approaches to improving health. Very strict oversight of use of biobanks and strong privacy provisions.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: I prioritized strong regulation, privacy protections, and public funding and oversight of biobanks.

1. There must be special consideration of the views of Aboriginal people towards healthcare and genetic research.

4. The community that provides samples for research should receive improved medical services in return.
5. Religious groups need to be asked for their views about biobanks and genetic research.
6. Commercial companies should keep all the profits they make from biobanking because they take the financial risks and put up the money to develop new drugs and treatments.
7. The public will be more protected if biobanks are government-funded not privately funded.
8. Public funds should pay for biobanks, instead of private companies.
9. Biobanks are valuable even if they only advance science (e.g. provide new information about diseases) and do not lead to treatments or cures.
10. My sample should never be permanently anonymized since I should be contacted about important research results
11. Genetic studies will lead to the discrimination of people living with genetic conditions or disabilities.
12. Information about people's genes and the traits they inherit from their parents is more private than their medical records.
13. Policy makers need to consider whether WA should not have biobanks.
14. I should have property rights to my tissues before and after they leave my body
15. There is no point asking the public for their views on the ethical issues in science and technology.
16. I trust researchers to make sure only approved people get access to my samples
17. It is acceptable for samples and information that doesn't identify me to be sent to researchers overseas.
18. People should always be able to withdraw their sample from research at any time.
19. People who provide samples for research should get special access to the treatments that result from this research.
20. I trust independent research ethics committees, which are not connected to the biobank in anyway, to decide whether research is ethical and approve who gets access to my samples.
21. The confidentiality of personal medical information is critical in any circumstance where research is being conducted.
22. I trust biobanks with managers who are independent of researchers to make sure only approved people get access to my samples
23. Collecting samples from people in an ethnic or cultural group is acceptable only if the whole group has agreed to participate.
24. Race is a useful topic for genetic studies
25. Commercial companies should get access to biobanks, otherwise new drugs and treatments will not be developed.
26. There is no risk to the people who provide samples and information to biobanks.
27. People should be paid for providing their samples to a biobank.
28. People should be told if commercial companies could get access to their samples and information.
29. The priorities for health should be to reduce inequalities and the burden of disease.
30. People who provide samples should be active in the set up and ongoing management of biobanks.
31. I should be asked for my permission every time researchers want to use my samples for research
32. Biobanks will only lead to high profits and expensive treatments that most people can't afford.
33. Permission from the indigenous community must be sought if samples are collected from indigenous peoples.
34. I don't mind if my samples are connected to my medical records without my prior permission, so long as researchers don't get access to any data that identifies me.
35. We should all provide samples to biobanks because it will benefit everyone.
36. It's OK if data that identifies me is stored in a separate database and replaced in the biobank by a unique non-identifying code.
37. I do not mind if my sample is connected to my name and medical information.
38. Improved health is more likely to come from educating people about their diet and lifestyle than from biobanks.

40. I do not mind if researchers have access to my samples, when there is no way I can be identified.
41. High-priced genetic research is diverting funds that could be used to promote public health in other ways.
42. The biobank owner should be able to sell any information they have about my genes, if they want to.
43. Biobanks need to be monitored and reviewed by external, independent people to prevent the misuse of data and samples.
44. Genetic research will improve our lives.
45. Deciding how to regulate biobanks should be left to the government.
46. People with a [chronic disease or] genetic condition in their family have a responsibility to be involved in genetic research.
47. Biobanks are valuable because they promise huge benefits for our economy.
48. Researchers and institutions (e.g. hospitals and universities) should be allowed to use samples for research but they should not own them.
49. The fact that we cannot predict what biobanks will be used for in the future bothers me.

- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: I prioritized strong regulation, privacy protections, and public funding over private interests.

## [Example output]:
